CHOCOLATE CHIP COOKIES RECIPE  Ingredients      120g butter, softened     75g light brown sugar     75g golden caster sugar     1 medium egg     1 tsp vanilla extract     180g plain flour     ½ tsp bicarbonate of soda     150g dark chocolate, cut into chunks      STEP 1  Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and line two baking sheets with parchment. Cream the butter and sugars together until very light and fluffy, then beat in the egg and vanilla. Once combined, stir in the flour, bicarb, chocolate and ¼ tsp salt.      STEP 2  Scoop 10 large tbsps of the mixture onto the trays, leaving enough space between each to allow for spreading. Bake for 10-12 mins or until firm at the edges but still soft in the middle – they will harden a little as they cool. Leave to cool on the tray for a few mins before eating warm, or transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. Will keep for three days in an airtight container.

[h1]Oatmeal Chocolate Chip Cookies[/h1] [hr][/hr]   [list]     [*] 1 and 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour     [*] 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon (optional)     [*] 1 teaspoon baking soda     [*] 1 teaspoon salt     [*] 1 cup (2 sticks; 230g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature     [*] 1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar     [*] 1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar     [*] 2 large eggs, at room temperature     [*] 1 Tablespoon unsulphured or dark molasses     [*] 2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract     [*] 3 cups (240g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats     [*] 1 and 3/4 cups semi-sweet chocolate chips   [/list] [hr][/hr]   [olist]     [*] Whisk the flour, cinnamon, baking soda, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.     [*] In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium-high speed until smooth, about 1 minute. Add the brown sugar and granulated sugar and beat on medium-high speed until creamed, about 2 minutes. Add the eggs, molasses, and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.     [*] Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, beat in the oats and both types of chocolate chips. Dough will be thick and sticky. Cover and chill the dough for at least 45 minutes in the refrigerator (and up to 4 days). If chilling for longer than a few hours, allow to sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before rolling and baking because the dough will be quite hard.     [*] Preheat oven to 350°F (177°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.     [*] Use a large cookie scoop to scoop the cookie dough, about 3 Tablespoons of dough per cookie, and place 4 inches apart on the baking sheets. Bake for 13-14 minutes or until lightly browned on the sides. The centers will look very soft.     [*]  Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. While the cookies are still warm, I like to press a few more chocolate chips into the tops– this is only for looks!   [/olist] [hr][/hr] [i] Cookies stay fresh covered at room temperature for up to 1 week. [/i] [hr][/hr]

Well sure seems like a normal idle game to me.  [b]2nd Hour:[/b] Ok so I understand a factory for making cookies but why can I buy a farm,mine,bank,temple and a freaking wizard tower that ,,Summons cookies with magic spells?"  [b]3rd Hour:[/b] So apparently I found this feature named ,,Legacy" and it's some sort of reset for my game but I need to bake 1 trillion cookies? How am I supposed to do that? Maybe this alchemy lab or that portal that,, Opens a door to the Cookieverse" could help me.  [b]5th Hour:[/b] My hand is getting numb from all this clickin-..wait..what's a sugar lump and why do I need to wait 24 hours for it to ripen?  [b]8th Hour:[/b] These golden cookies that randomly pop on my screen are insane for making cookies. I can even combo them if I wait long enough so I can have 2 buffs at the same time and I am almost ready to do my first Legacy.  [b]9th Hour:[/b] How did I play this game for 9 hours straight? My friends and family have been asking if I've been okay recently.  "Yeah, why?" I ask quizzically.  They proceed to tell me that the cookies, they aren't real. They don't exist. It's just a fabrication on a computer. I tell them it's not true, they're lying.  "No, seriously ZeroTuwu, they're not real."  I ignore them. The grandmatriarchs love me and I love them. My time invested in such a masterfully created game... There is just simply no way it would be a false prophet. The clicks and time invested into such a creation, it can only yield good results that would benefit me in real life.  "But what about us?" asks my family. "We exist and you're not giving us half the attention you give that game."  "It's simple..." I say. "The people of the Cookie Clicker universe love me more than you ever will."  My Mum sobs, my Dad throws me out of the house, but it doesn't matter. Cookie Clicker is eternal. 10/10.

Cookie Clicker is damaging to yourself and those around you.  Cookie Clicker is an addiction. Based on my extensive naturalistic observation, I have seen how far a person can and will go in order to keep clicking cookies. This behaviour is very closely related to the behaviour of addicts, supporting my statement about Cookie Clicker being an addiction.  Cookie Clicker is the only thing on the effected person's mind. Even during the short periods where Cookie Clicker is not being played, the addicted individual will talk about Cookie Clicker any chance they get. Unfortunately, many people I know have faced this horrible addiction and I have seen how it takes over their minds. One time, while I was helping an addicted child overcome his problem, another addicted man came and stole the conversation from me turning it into a twisted talk of obsession. There was another time that really stood out in my mind about how Cookie Clicker is always on the effected individual's mind. I was in the car with two addicted individuals and was trying to have a normal, healthy, conversation with one. Sadly, the other person interrupted the conversation to talk about his cookies, and in doing so, he ruined a game that me and the other addicted person have been playing for years. That was truly a soul crushing moment for me.  As the addiction gets worse, the effected person will forgo any form of healthy social interaction to feed his addiction. There have been many times where I would try to enjoy some social time with a person who is addicted to Cookie Clicker, but they will always choose the game over real people. Sometimes, although it is rare, they will participate in social activity, but their thoughts are quickly consumed by cookies and it shows in their choice of conversation.  Like any addiction, the Cookie Clicker addiction is damaging to those who care for the addicted individual. The addiction will cause those who care for the effected person to feel guilty. The addicted person's family may feel responsible for that person's addiction. They will question how they have allowed them to develop an addiction, or perhaps they fought hard to help the addicted individual but were not able to help. Regardless of the circumstances, those who are close to the addicted individual will carry guilt and blame themselves to a certain extent.  As I mentioned earlier, I know people that are effected by this horrid game. I have seen others try to explain to them how damaging a simple game could be but they refuse to listen, and to some extent, those people blame themselves for not trying hard enough and letting them get sucked into this dark place. Another way it could affect those around the effected person is by them downplaying the problem. Like any addiction, people close to the person could just live in denial about the effected person's problem. They might make excuses for the person's behaviour or downplay the problem. They could also be scared about addressing the issue, worried about the possible future for the person, so they choose to ignore it instead of dealing with it.  At first I thought that this Cookie Clicker was a simple, although completely boring, game. Oh how wrong I was. The game slowly consumes the players, like a child eating cookies. I thought it was just going to be another game that people would quickly get bored of or forget about a few days later, and because of these thoughts, the Cookie Clicker addiction had time to fully manifest itself in their minds, since no one was trying to stop them. Another way it damages those around the addicted person, is that the addiction controls their mind. When people are addicted to something their whole life revolves around the addiction. It consumes their mind turning them into a different person, which is scary to those around them. Instead of the person seeing you as someone who cares for them, they will only see you as someone who is getting in the way of the only thing they care about, Cookie Clicker. You can try all you want to help the person get over this Cookie Clicker, but they won't see it that way. You could turn the computer off, but instead of the nice person you knew and cared for they will turn into some monster, screaming at you for making them lose their precious cookies. They are no longer the person you cared for.  Playing Cookie Clicker even just once is dangerous. Like any addictive thing, it may take only one time to become addicted. Cookie Clicker has just enough stuff for someone to keep on "playing" right from the beginning. At first you start with nothing, but as you continue clicking you gather enough cookies for upgrades, which make it so you can get more cookies faster, making you repeat an endless cycle of pain.  Cookie Clicker also has achievements for you to get, which keeps you hooked on the game. Not only does it have the upgrades that were mentioned earlier, but it also has achievements. Some of these achievement titles prove that the creators of the game are well aware that it's an addiction by having the achievement titles relate to drug use. One achievement is "So baked right now", another is "Overdose", and these sayings clearly show the relations to drug use.  Even if you manage to beat this addiction there is always the possibility of having a relapse. Unfortunately, no one I know has overcome this problem, but based on my knowledge of addictions, it's a very real possibility that they could suffer from a relapse. Relapses are a miserable part of addiction, even after you overcome the problem there is still a chance it could come back at any time. Possibly because of stress, negative emotions, really strong cravings, or being around things that remind you of Cookie Clicker. It is very damaging to your life and you might have to avoid cookies for the rest of your life unless you want to relapse. So you shouldn't play the game, even just once.  By now you should realize how dangerous this so called "game" is and the harmful effects it has on not only the player, but also those who care for the player. I truly hope that this paper will open people's eyes about this so called game, and that anyone who reads this won't let anyone they care for get sucked into this Cookie Clicker.

There are enough satirical reviews, so I'll try to write something more robust. I played it for a long time in the browser and did not hesitate to grab this Steam version.  This is the king of idle games, in my opinion. Ironically, it's because the game can be pretty engaging if you're out to play actively and find interesting combinations in your never-ending goal to make more cookies. On the other hand, if you just want to leave it running, that's fine too. I'm sure the game provides a worthwhile critique of aggressive and near-nihilistic devotion to capitalist expansion, but I'm just going to focus on the gameplay for the time being...  You click the cookie to make cookies. Then you buy things that make cookies for you. Then you unlock upgrades that make even more cookies. Then you unlock minigames that allow you to make cookies while you make cookies. You make enough cookies to end the universe as we know it. But it doesn't end. It goes on, because you need to make more cookies.  If this sounds fun to you, you should try it out. The developer is and has been devoted to improving the game for years now, so we're likely getting more cookie production, more cookie minigames, and - ultimately - more cookies. An underrated aspect of the game is its flavourful aesthetic, news headlines, and Lovecraftian comedy (without spoiling too much).  With the variety of buildings, upgrades, and minigames, you can find the way you want to play. You can't really play the game 'incorrectly'. Do you want to just run it in the background and check in once a day to buy upgrades? Sure. Keep an eye on it to catch golden cookies? That works. Or try to run your minigames and spells in a way to chase incredibly large boosts of cookies in short bursts? You can do that too.  It doesn't matter, but it is fun. Just keep making cookies.

Among many idle games, one game that stands out is Cookie Clicker. The gameplay is straightforward and simple, you click cookies to buy upgrades and these upgrades will get you more cookies. This game's basic concept, however, will not deter any curious person from enjoying this game for many hours. Cookie Clicker has a unique charm to it that keeps its players hooked, that, which is best explained by experiencing it for oneself. For the price of $4.99, Cookie Clicker has kept me entertained for well over 100 hours of active play, though, the rest I did leave it idling. Throughout all my current 247 hours, I have yet to experience a single bug, which just shows how well polished the game is, a feature that I do not see too common these days. Cookie Clicker has been one of the best purchases I made on Steam, and I recommend this game to any person that is looking for something fun, and or to burn some time.

Cookie Clicker is a bizarre game and one that makes me wish that Steam had something better than a binary Yes/No review system, as this game can probably work well for some people but horribly for others. I have tried to keep this review as short as possible, but with enough depth to let you know whether this game could be for you.   The idea that idle games can form some sort of critique of modern games (especially with RPG elements increasingly commonplace) is well-worn and incredibly applicable to Cookie Clicker, and whilst some idle games have started charging for in-game purchases, Cookie Clicker is admirably devoid of them. The real question for someone approaching this is whether what Cookie Clicker does is subversive enough to warrant putting time into it at all.   [b]The Good-ish[/b] I wouldn't want to spoil what ends up happening in this game to anyone buying it and not really knowing what they are getting into, but the trailer on the Steam page and some of the screenshots already do that. This game's story and lore scale in a bizarre way that in its absurdity is incredibly compelling. The progression of buildings at a glance does an effective job at hinting towards this; whilst you start off buying cursors to click the cookie, you soon employ Grandma's to bake more cookies, farms to grow them, mines to them, banks to generate them from interest and much, much more including temples, wizards, alchemy and some fourth-wall breaking ironic inclusions. As the "tech tree" progresses, a news reel at the top of your window will start to report on the world of cookie clicker, and it is here than the real "lore" of the game comes out - it really is very well done; never are we given enough detail do build a coherent view of the world, but the specificity of the comments offer us unique yet contained viewpoints of the world. You could see this as looking upon a massive jigsaw through through many tiny and dispersed holes in a wall.   As the Steam page shows, at a certain point this game will bring an apocalypse,  cookie demons, and reincarnation. The absurdity is the game's biggest strength.  [b]The Bad-ish[/b] Whilst there are reasons like the short paragraph above to come to this game - there are caveats and certain things to be warned of going into it. The numbers go up in an amazing and rewarding way, but it is ultimately pointless. That wouldn't be an issue if it weren't for the golden cookies; these are cookies than spawn on screen, and when clicked, offer a buff to cookie production or a lump sum of cookies. If you are actively clicking those golden cookies, you can get hours worth of progress done in a few minutes - but given how the numbers go up and to no real end, you eventually do need to ask yourself why you want to click the golden cookies at all. I do not think that the game is a waste of mental energy at all; I quite enjoyed doing some mental arithmetic to work out which building would yield the most cookies per second (CpS) - and anything that gets you doing mental maths instead of just staring at YouTube is surely good. The problem really is in the golden cookie chase - I found it pretty easy to ignore them and only click them when I happened to be tabbed onto the screen, but at a certain point you unlock a sound cue for them; this is the really 'dangerous' part of the game. The sound cue is optional and can be toggled off; the problem is whether or not you have the willpower to do it. For a while I left it on assuming golden cookies were rare enough and valuable enough to be worth tabbing to the program and clicking - but as you get your ascension perks and with the right deities in place (as said prior, this game really does go places...) the rate at which golden cookies appear  gets overwhelming. If you have the self control to turn that sound cue off and not care about the golden cookies then this criticism will mean little to you; but there are definitely people for whom the sound cue will act as all too strong a distraction. That's important to me, for the following reason...  [b]So...?[/b] Ultimately, I have said "Yes" that I recommend this game. When we can take an ironic distance from the game and enjoy it for what it is, namely; a subversive idle game that reveals an absurd world through its progression and news reel, it is wonderful. But when we lose the ironic detachment from it and start to care about the golden cookies and the numbers going up, the game ceases to work in that subversive and absurdist way.   If you think you will care too much about the golden cookies and the numbers, I thoroughly recommend watching a breakdown video or reading some article going over the whole Cookie Clicker lore. If you won't, then I think Cookie Clicker could be a good idle game for you.

[h2][b][u]Recommendation:[/u][/b] Play the Browser Version[/h2] [b][u]tl;dr:[/u][/b] Just gonna lay it out flat: This is largely a replica of the freely-available browser version, so if you think you might be interested just take that for a spin instead. That said, there are three reasons you may want to plunk down $5 (or less if it's on discount) for this version: [olist] [*] Has a very pleasant/chill soundtrack (browser game just has beeps and bloops) [*] Steam Achievements (currently 500+; browser game just has in-game boring badges) [*] To give a little financial support if you've already played the game for a while [/olist]  [h1]Did It All For The Cookie[/h1] I gave the the browser version a shot not long after it first exploded in popularity (roughly Dec 2013) and was hooked. (According to Cookie Clicker my bakery started "a long while ago" because it didn't always track the start date.) Eventually I did far more idling than clicking, but I still let it run in a tab whenever my PC was on. Once a year or so there'd be a large update and I'd give it some extra focus. I'd also ascend 1-4 times per year out of boredom, to unlock Heavenly perks and increase my prestige, spending more time in it for a few days before letting it fall back to idler status.  And this game is [i]nearly[/i] a one-for-one replication of the browser game. (I wouldn't be surprised if it was running in some form of Chromium, in fact.) So while Cookie Clicker only released on Steam barely a day ago, I have 7+ years of experience with it. Is it a good game? Sure. You click the cookie to make cookies , buy things to click the cookie or create cookies on your behalf, unlock/buy upgrades, and a handful of micromanaging. "Minigames" such as a garden and stock market increase the gameplay variety. The achievements and their descriptions have amusing puns and references. A scrolling news ticker along the time can also offer a chuckle (oh, and unlocks.) There are business kittens and scary cookies.  But... it's still an idler game, so you get as much out of as the time you (don't) put into it. If it weren't for the browser version my recommendation would be to buy on heavy discount, though I don't think $5 standard price is bad for this (particularly with all the updates released since the initial 2013 launch.) Speaking of which, there are some fringe differences between this and the browser version: [list] [*][b]Heralds[/b] are now based on concurrent players (max 100) rather than the number of Patreon top pledges [*]The existing Achievements directly translate to [b]Steam Achievements[/b], currently 500+ available. If you're one of those who likes massive achievement numbers, here ya go. (But these are all legit achievements, not really achievement farming... I'll circle back to this) [*][b]Cloud saves[/b] mean no more lost games due to lost cookies/PC... but also means it's far harder to recover from a bad RNG. In the browser if I didn't like the result of a click, I could quickly hit F5 to reload (losing <60 seconds of progress and saving my bakery from the roll). With this you can still close the program, but the risk of an autosave occurring is larger and it's more of a hassle to get back into the game [*][b]Music[/b] has been added, giving a nice, chill soundtrack made by C418 (who did music for Minecraft.) I like it, but either I need to do something to unlock more tracks or there are only 3-4 tracks as I seem to already have plenty of repeats. You could consider this a $5 album with bonus idle clicker game, which I view as a legit way to think about it [/list]  At this point I'm uncertain I'll move to the Steam version to continue my bakery into year 8 (9?) or continue in the browser, but either way I don't regret the $5 spent. Plus, if I decide to stick with the browser I can take the progress I've made in the Steam version and import it there. Ah, that's right: You can export the data from your browser instance and import it into here. I did after first launching it and received 490 Steam achievements (taking about 10 minutes to go through the whole list). So for those who have already "played" Cookie Clicker for thousands of hours, the $5 might be worth it if you like Steam Achievement bragging rights.  One thing I should note regarding my recommendation is that for the past few months the browser version has been unreliable in loading. Once it loads there's no issue, but sometimes I have to refresh the page a few times to get that load to happen. The Steam release is probably making this worse as people go to check out the browser version.

Really a great and classic clicker and idle game. Initially released in 2013, it is now out on steam with tons and tons of new feature and content. I remember playing this in my uni library way back in 2015 so playing this now gives me a nice nostalgia trip.  Though it does look the same as i remember with being familiar with all these different upgrades like the grandmas and such. There are some new things that are new which is cool to see. Gameplay wise is quite fun for a clicker game with there being a lot to do in terms of gaining an endless amount of cookies. Hundreds of upgrades, and a whole of of source of gaining them cookies and mini games to play making you come back for more and have that feeling of playing just a bit more for the time. It is is nice and satisfying to see the numbers build up with the clicks per second by clicking and idling.   Visually, it has a simple look to it with an accessible user interface which is easy to play with. All the content within looks great and is accompanied with some nice music to listen to as you click and idle. Price wise, it is quite cheap. I know that there is the free web version, but it is totally worth it to buy and have it on steam if you wish. From the game itself having a ton of content, making it deserved of the price to the features ingame as well as out of game. Having steam cloud is a really nice feature as i remember when i was playing it years back, I would play starting over from scratch from time to time, so having this feature is really nice for picking up and playing again even in the long future. There are hundreds of achievements with the steam achievements and it correlating with the achievements ingame with each having their own icon. Collecting them all, which would take a lot of time of course, adds to the playability and replayability as you try and collect as one as you keep on idling, clicking and playing.  With it just coming on steam, later on there apparently will be even more features like steam workshop. Am quite looking forward to how the game will develop even more. Overall, definitely worth it if you're into clickers and idle games, or have enjoyed playing the free web version in the past. It is a chill and casual game welcoming to all. This game saved my life.  I am 27.  My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.  When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.  After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.  Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.  After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.  Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.  I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.  Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.  Thank you

TLDR: great game, but this version is buggy, clogs up your ram, interferes with other games running at the same time, and any new progress made in this version can't be transferred back to the browser version, so you're boxed in.  Update: The first patch is out, and it fixes 'the game will not let you close it' problem, as well as the memory leak (I think?  Not 100% on that) but the interface still bugs out sometimes, and it still borks controller support.  That controller thing is a really big deal, hope that gets fixed soon.  I want to preface this by saying I absolutely love this game, it's great, best idle game ever made, but the steam version is in pretty rough shape right now, and if you transfer your save to the steam version, you can't transfer any new progress back to the browser version because they have different version numbers, so you're kinda stuck with it.  Let me explain why that's an issue.  There are three key problems with the game at the moment: it's buggy, it has a memory leak, and it breaks controller support for any other games running at the same time.  The first problem is the most minor - nothing completely breaks, the interface just goes a bit wonky under certain circumstances, and, weirdly, the game will under no circumstances let you close it unless you kill the right process in the task manager.  Irritating, but not a big deal.  The second two problems are where the real issue lies.  This is a game that wants to be running at any time your computer is on.  Even with heavenly upgrades, the game punishes you for closing it with dramatically reduced CPS, so closing it should be avoided if at all possible.  This wasn't really an issue with the browser version, just leave your browser open and it'll chug along in the background, but this version has a small memory leak, so it will fill up a slowly-increasing volume of RAM over time, and, imo, much more seriously, the game breaks controller support in anything else that's running because it uses a javascript library that hijacks controller input.  If you want to play anything else with this game running in the background, you'd better hope it isn't a fighting game, racing game, or something else that wants to be played with a controller, or you'll need to close cookie clicker in order to use that controller.  I've been playing a lot of fighting games lately so when I realised this was an issue, I figured 'no big deal, I'll just take my progress back to the web version', only you can't - the steam version has a higher version number, so any progress you make in steam is bound to steam, until the web version is updated to the same version number.  I'm put in a weird position where I can only have this game running when I'm afk, or avoid playing the games I want to play in order to tiptoe around this game breaking controller support, and I can't just go back to the old version because I've made significant progress in this save that I don't want to lose.  At the end of the day, if you like the original, I think you should buy it, support the dev, but maybe wait on transferring your save to steam until these issues get ironed out.

A woman in a grocery store happens upon a grandfather and his poorly behaved 3 year-old grandson. It's obvious to her that the grandfather has his hands full with the child screaming for cookies in the confectionery aisle.  Meanwhile, Gramps is working his way around, muttering in a controlled voice, "Easy, Julien, we won't be long - easy, boy." Another outburst and she hears Gramps calmly say, "Its okay, Julien, just a couple more minutes and we'll be out of here. Hang in there boy."  At the checkout, the little terror is throwing items out of the cart, screaming, and Gramps again in a controlled voice whispers “Julien, Julien, relax buddy, don't get upset. We'll be home in five minutes; stay cool, Julien."   Very impressed, the woman goes outside where Gramps is loading his groceries and the boy into the car. "You know, sir, it's none of my business, but you were amazing in there. I don't know how you did it. That whole time, you kept your composure, and no matter how loud and disruptive he got, you just calmly kept saying things would be okay. Julien is very lucky to have you as his grandpa."  “Thanks, lady," said Gramps, "But, I'm Julien - the little sh!t’s name is Ian."

Here's a recipe for cookies: Preparation time: 40min  Ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour 1/2 teaspoon baking soda 1/2 teaspoon salt 3/4 cup unsalted butter melted 1 cup packed brown sugar 1/2 cup white sugar 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 1 egg 1 egg yolk 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips  Procedure: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper. Sift together the flour, baking soda and salt; set aside. In a medium bowl, cream together the melted butter, brown sugar and white sugar until well blended. Beat in the vanilla, egg, and egg yolk until light and creamy. Mix in the sifted ingredients until just blended. Stir in the chocolate chips by hand using a wooden spoon. Drop cookie dough 1/4 cup at a time onto the prepared cookie sheets. Cookies should be about 3 inches apart. Bake for 15 to 17 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the edges are lightly toasted. Cool on baking sheets for a few minutes before transferring to wire rack.﻿

I would really, really, like to recommend this, but in its current state, I can't. I love Cookie Clicker. I've played it on and off since its initial release, and I've seen the game grow from Classic to its current iteration.  However, the Steam version presents multiple very frustrating issues: Lost save data appears to be a common issue, and due to its nature as an idle game this can mean hours of time lost. Why this would be released with an utterly broken save feature is beyond me, but in the meantime all I can suggest is manually exporting/importing saves as necessary .... I also have issues with the game frequently crashing either on startup or shortly after, and often requiring use of Task Manager to properly close the game after it crashes.  It's sad, but the free browser version really does offer a better and more stable experience, in my opinion.

On August 8, 2013, Cookie Clicker is released.   200 years later, the Earth is destroyed in nuclear hellfire; over 2 millenia of progress is reduced to ash in a matter of hours. Pollution and radiation render the planet uninhabitable to all but the most resilient microbes and bacterium.   3,000 years later, a small team of cosmic archaeologists depart from a distant solar system to explore the remnants of human civilization, tasked with understanding how and why our civilization faltered. Despite the breadth of our history and culture, there is little to be found amongst the detritus, and our visitors begin to wonder if perhaps these ruins are the only evidence we existed at all.   After days of rummaging through ash and detritus, the explorers stumble upon a lone building, still standing amongst the devastation. It is in remarkably good condition, given the circumstances. After running a quick analysis with their scanners, the cosmonauts discover that the building is somehow still generating and consuming electricity. As they move in to investigate, they find something beyond belief:    A single computer still running Cookie Clicker. The last remnant of human civilization.   Suddenly, it all makes sense.

There is something that incremental games simply do not get; your backup system has to have several layers of redundancy. I have 85 hours played (about 30% of that active) and my game has been lost due to steam cloud.  I know that's an insignificant amount of time in the grand scheme of an incremental; but regardless, if you can't provide better backups than playing in a browser; why are is this on Steam?  Unless you can be diligent in regularly exporting your saves or have a tolerance for a potentially significant amount of rollback when the cloud backup fails; then don't bother playing this on Steam.

It's Cookie Clicker, but worse, specifically because whatever they've done to the Electron base app they're using to run the usual web game's javascript on the desktop makes it extremely prone to crashing. I've had it running for roughly 12 hours cumulative at time of writing and the program has crashed no less than SEVEN times, three of which were on start up. And whenever it crashes, it always seems to leave behind a stray electron process that I have to manually kill before steam thinks the program is actually dead and I can restart it.  Plus, I'm the kind of person to start poking at the games innards when I get bored, and this version doesn't have easy access to the developer's console, so that's already a step down from the web version even before the stability issues.

Introduction:  Cookie clicker is a fantastic game but to really appreciate its complex nature we must look at each aspect individually and understand what really ties this generation defining game together.   Gameplay:  The gameplay goals are relatively simple. More cookies…make more cookies! You start with an empty glass and no milk or cookies. Each click gives you a cookie, a process I wish was true of real life. Eventually, you will click your way to your first upgraded idle clicker. The more cookies you can stock up on the more upgrades you can purchase from the store. Before you know it, you will have ascended that solum 1 cookie per click to farms, baking you thousands if not millions within a reasonably short amount of time. You can also invest your cookies into power-ups. Such as your cookie farm becoming twice as effective or an increased percentage per click.  As you continue to build your cookie balance you can buy more and more upgrades increasing your idle cookies per second. Once you eventually get to the next available balance milestone you will unlock the next upgradeable. Some of the earlier upgrades consist of; Grandma, Farm, Mine, and factory. The rest, you will have to find out for yourself.  There is also a Legacy section where you will be set a goal, the first being to bake a trillion cookies. Once you have hit this milestone you can then prestige if you wish or continue to gain levels by baking more cookies to spend more points on permanent upgrades. This will set you back to the very start of your journey but with powerful and permanent boosters to aid you. While playing make sure to keep an eye out for the golden cookies! Once activated these provide a powerful temporary boost such as a frenzy mode doubling your cookie production, or maybe you will receive a large injection of extra cookies to top up your balance.  There are also Sugar lumps. This is shown next to your cookie balance and takes a very long time to build/ mature. Once you have collected your sugar lump you can use this to level up your upgrades. Level 0 grants +0% CPS and each level after grants an increase to your CPS. Some buildings can give special perks such as temples allowing you to choose pantheons to give buffs to various attributes of the game, or wizard towers which give you access to powerful spells with a 15% chance of a backfire and a negative effect, or even upgrading the bank allowing you to access an in game stock market. Truly amazing.   Story:  Surprisingly the story in cookie clicker is vast and engaging with natural passing and unexpected turns. the story follows a simple concept of you the player opening a cookie store and expanding your baking empire. You will learn to increase production by taking advantage of investment opportunities by buying upgrades and buildings starting from the humble grandmas and eventually investing in full blown time machines and antimatter condensers. Unfortunately, things take a turn for you the young capitalist when you upgrade grandmas for means of production in complete negligence to all ethics, exploiting slave labour you use your power force hundreds of grandmas to work in these buildings including gruelling tasks on the farm and digging in the mines as the world around you bends towards your will creating an economy based on cookies while controlling a monopoly on all cookie suppliers. The news feed will attempt to warn you of these heinous deeds to insist to commit while you ignore every word and watch the cookies roll in. While keeping them grandmas cooped up in a retirement home they hatch an evil plan while communing with the demons beyond portals to gain their powers and take over the world as a rise of freedom from your oppression, sending worms to hijack your production and turning golden cookies into wrath cookies with chances of negative effects. The portrayal of capitalism and working party embargo creates remarkable depiction of what society could be like given the opportunity of extreme capitalism going out of hand without hindering the game experience to make these political undertones a hindrance by shoving propaganda disguised as a game in your face. Overall very impressive and inspiring.   Graphics and Audio:  Graphically the game isn’t very intense. It is, however very pleasing, even more so on the upgraded graphics given by steam. There are a number of small animations such as the moving background and the movement of the milk in the glass as well as a tabloid news feed hinting at potential foreshadowing of the story as well as flavour text which keep your attention well however aren't too distracting at the same time. The audio was very nice. The in-game music is soothing and relaxing thanks to the help of the fantastic work of c418 while little audio cues keep you aware of what is happening with a satisfying click keeps you engaged. There are also a lot of customisation options available in-game to tailor the experience to your own requirements.  the graphics develop drastically as you progress through the story, in the beginning as you just open a new corner side local cookie shop the graphics reflect that with pleasing to the eye blue and light blue vertical stripes with an extremely wholesome feel. As you progress and earn more you start to notice small cookies raining in the glass increasing exponentially. During the grandmapocalypse, an in-game event that begins after a long chain of upgrades these graphic changes become less subtle as the before wholesome cookie shop walls slowly turns into a dystopian love-craftion horror depiction of the harsh reality of capitalism within todays society with large flesh amorthic grandma blobs and horrific parasites that eat away at your cookie production. Luckily for the more faint hearted of you, the game has implemented an option that makes all these horrific changes redundant and gives the parasites googly eyes.   Longevity:  The Longevity of the game could be somewhat questionable. While it is not likely to be a game that you will be itching to play daily. It is a great game for relaxing or multitasking. If you enjoy a challenge there is over 600+ Upgrades and over 500+ achievements to work towards including many secrets and easter eggs in the form as shadow achievements. Including minigames such as growing farms and investing in stocks its unlikely for you to grow bored any time soon, and should the time arise where you have nothing left to do, leave the game running come back later and enjoy the fruits of your afk labour by investing a large sum of generated cookies you so rightfully earned. It is likely you may find yourself with hundreds of hours in the game however due to the nature of afk games the actual playtime can be left somewhat debated.   Conclusion:  Overall, I really enjoy the experience I receive playing Cookie Clicker. I found it peaceful and relaxing at night but also laid back enough to play while watching TV/ YouTube. I’ve also heard that it could be a great option for those long meetings at work if you’re still working from home. With the expansive story and ludicrous amounts of achievements and goals to achieve, I can’t see myself putting down the game anytime soon. With full modding support from the steam workshop to come and more updates up the developers sleeves I am optimistic in cookie clickers future.   Overall, I would rate cookie clicker a solid,  who gives a fuck? why are you even reading this shitty review / 10

There are two main categories for why this isn't recommended. The first is the technical issues, the second is the gameplay issues, so let's get into these.  First off, I did NOT have issues with save files being deleted, instead I've had a number of other problems that aren't really unexpected. Cookie clicker was written in javascript, which doesn't really handle user interfaces at high framerates very well in general and never really has. This leads to lag in everything from cookie clicker to the secret world, so I had hoped that the steam port would have changed from javascript to C++ or python or something, but alas it has not. This means random interface lag spikes on a fairly frequent basis, to the point they actually interfere with gameplay.  For example, not only can you visibly see lag spikes when trying to click the cookie quickly, where it'll pause for half a second at a time ignoring all input in that time, where a stream of numbers has a clear gap, the freezing has made certain things like the chain-cookie be broken due to freezing and ignoring inputs on a 1-2 second window of opportunity for rare events. This is frustrating, but not game breaking.  What is game breaking, however, is after I reached about the octillion range of cookies, the game stopped responding properly when tabbed out of it. If anything other than cookie clicker is the focus window, even with just like a text document partially obscuring the window but being the focus, cookie clicker slows down, then freezes entirely and it stops updating at all. it will sit there forever, without change, until you tab back into it. Several tests have confirmed that a golden cookie effect, such as the X7 frenzy, will sit there never going down, and you can time it for a minute, then tab back in, it'll jump ahead about 10 seconds quickly, then continue like nothing happened.  ...Yeah, an idle game which can't idle. You literally need to sit on the game at all times after a point to continue playing, rather than having it running in the background while you do other stuff. This completely defeats the entire purpose of an idle game, and for that reason alone, it would already be a negative review, but it doesn't end there.  Now we get into the gameplay issues.  Even if you have no technical issues with the game, the gameplay... well, cookie clicker was, to my knowledge, the very first idle game. It hasn't exactly aged well. Compared to other idle games, it requires an enormous amount of attention paid to the game, and progresses incredibly slowly.  Even when you're just first starting the game, it takes a very long time to get it up and running properly, and you start hitting long progress walls very quickly.  I first started cookie clicker this time because I was hit with the nasty flu going around this year, and couldn't concentrate on much anything other than an idle game for a few days. This meant spending basically 100% of my waking hours focused on cookie clicker actively, getting all the golden cookies and so on. It still took about 2.5 days for the first acension reset at 113 chips. For most other more modern games in the genre, this usually takes about 1-3 hours for the same effect.  The progression is... slow. Even with building up a large cookie store and doing the x7 +lucky cookie bonus (combo occurs roughly every 3.5 minutes if you're actively playing for about 220 minutes worth of production bonus), it still will produce almost nothing of real progression.  The one exception to this, is an odd spike where if you unlock the magic "minigame" and keep it stocked up in reserve, and wait for a x7 bonus, then also a x41 or so building multiplier, then trigger the magic effect to generate a new golden cookie with about a 25% chance to trigger a click frenzy X777 clicking bonus, you can increase your cookie total by a factor of about 1,000x where you would otherwise be reasonably able to attain. This doesn't really allow you to progress from that point, but it does let you unlock a lot of achievements and have more golden chips to spend when you do the ascension reset. Using this, in 4 resets I was able to get into the decillion range of cookies and ran into a new set of problems which is very bad... running out of stuff to do.  I'm only a few days into the game and already the cursor building has run out of all upgrades. The last upgrade for it showed up at 450 cursors and I'm already up to 550 now. Grandmas are about to run dry, and looking at the upgrades which are available, it's clear that this is going to cause a real problem soon, because the scaling of the game is about for every 1,000x more cookies you get, your production goes up by about x60. This is falling off quickly as there are fewer upgrades to purchase, fewer achievements, and they don't scale infinitely, but rather every upgrade and achievement are individually crafted with amusing text descriptions, which is nice, keeps the game funny and enjoyable while they last, but unlike an infinite scaling setup it means they start running out fast too.  In short, the gameplay of the game is running out only a few days into the game. Yes, there are new things gradually opened up to unlock, but it's at the expense of previous, standardized things becoming defunct. Also, the newer gameplay elements take days at a time to be beneficial, built for extremely long play. The problem with this, as covered, is that the game is bizarrely active, and you're expected to click a golden cookie roughly every 90-110 seconds or suffer a huge loss in production and the game is balanced around the assumption you are doing this continually for days on end. You can't tab out properly as discussed earlier, and you can't really 'do' anything of value except wait for the next golden cookie to spawn every 1.5 to 2 minutes.  So... yeah. As an idle game, it's kind of really just not that good. It has a place in terms of history as being the first idle game, and if you're sick for a week it's an alright way to burn some time, but... as an idle game goes, it's too active to be idle, and the idle upgrades to make it possible to turn it off come in too late and are vastly inferior to playing actively to the point it's not really worth bothering with.  If you want an active idle game, go play Idle Wizard instead. I can't really recommend cookie clicker compared to the other free options out there when it just does the same thing as others but worse. It clearly has not kept up with newer innovations in the idle clicker genre.  If nothing else, the fact that it's still running on javascript alone should be good enough of a warning to stay away from it.

I used to be a cookie clicker addict, but I had been clean for years. Every once in a while I'd feel the urge to open up my browser and return to my roots, but my loving and supportive family would remind me of what's important in life. Then I saw the game on Steam. My world froze. My hands shook. My clicker finger got itchy and started to twitch. I knew what I had to do. Much to my family's dismay, I purchased the game. My wife took the kids to stay over at her parents house. But it doesn't matter, not anymore. The only thing that matters is cookies. It has ALWAYS been the cookies. There is no room in my life for anything else.

Here's a recipe for cookies: Preparation time: 40min  Ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour 1/2 teaspoon baking soda 1/2 teaspoon salt 3/4 cup unsalted butter melted 1 cup packed brown sugar 1/2 cup white sugar 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 1 egg 1 egg yolk 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips  Procedure: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper. Sift together the flour, baking soda and salt; set aside. In a medium bowl, cream together the melted butter, brown sugar and white sugar until well blended. Beat in the vanilla, egg, and egg yolk until light and creamy. Mix in the sifted ingredients until just blended. Stir in the chocolate chips by hand using a wooden spoon. Drop cookie dough 1/4 cup at a time onto the prepared cookie sheets. Cookies should be about 3 inches apart. Bake for 15 to 17 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the edges are lightly toasted. Cool on baking sheets for a few minutes before transferring to wire rack.﻿

[h1] Here's a recipe for cookies, or how I came to understand the existential dread that life has in store for us [/h1]  [b] Ingredients: [/b] 2 cups all-purpose flour 1/2 teaspoon baking soda 1/2 teaspoon salt 3/4 cup unsalted butter melted 1 cup packed brown sugar 1/2 cup white sugar 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 1 egg 1 egg yolk 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips  [b] Procedure: [/b] Preheat the oven to 325 degrees F (165 degrees C). Grease cookie sheets or line with parchment paper. Sift together the flour, baking soda and salt; set aside. In a medium bowl, cream together the melted butter, brown sugar and white sugar until well blended. Beat in the vanilla, egg, and egg yolk until light and creamy. Mix in the sifted ingredients until just blended. Stir in the chocolate chips by hand using a wooden spoon. Drop cookie dough 1/4 cup at a time onto the prepared cookie sheets. Cookies should be about 3 inches apart. Bake for 15 to 17 minutes in the preheated oven, or until the edges are lightly toasted. Cool on baking sheets for a few minutes before transferring to wire rack.﻿  Or at least, that's what they tell you. You see, for years I have been trying to perfect my cookie business. After graduating a prestigious university with a degree in baking, I spent the next fifteen years of my life attempting to perfect the cookie formula. For hours on end I would try hundreds of different cookie recipes, hoping to find the one that satisfied my needs. Whenever a kid on the block was selling cookies, I would run over their pitiful stand with my car when they took a bathroom break. I cannot let any competitors attempt to coerce my potential customers with their youthful presence. Some say this may not be morally correct, I disagree. This business is ruthless, and the way I see it I'm toughening these kids up. If they think they can leave their entire base of operations unattended for any amount of time, well they are sorely mistaken. But now I'm getting off topic.  So here I was, destroying my competitors and researching the perfect combination of ingredients for my cookie recipe. I had started to befriend my neighbors grandma's, in order to research them. You see, grandmas seem to have a special connection to the cookie world, and I wanted to use that. If I could not become them, I would just have to use them to strengthen my own recipe. Slowly, I had become acquainted with hundreds, if not thousands of different grandmothers. I started renting out garages, inviting them in masses to bake cookies for hours under the ploy of "baking for the homeless". This lead the business to gain some notoriety overtime, and the profits began to grow. But it still wasn't enough. You see, even after extracting many formulas from the elderly, it still didn't seem to be good enough for me. Yes, that was the best year we have had financially, but I couldn't help but feel like something was missing.  And so I stopped focusing on the business, and spent my time in search of more recipes to try. This was when I met Guillermo. Guillermo was a famous baker from italy, who I happened to meet during one of my many travels across the world in search of the chosen one. When I had first tried one of his cookies, I couldn't believe what I had just bitten into. It was the most magnificent thing I had ever placed my taste buds on. Right at that very moment, I knew he had to be the one.  And so, I made sweet love to him that very night. And then we made sweet love the next night. And the night after that. I made him fall madly in love with me, and offered to take him back to the US with me, where my business was still awaiting me. We returned to the factory, and I immediately locked him in a cage and sent him back to work. Our cookies finally became world renowned, known as the most delicious pastry to ever be offered. I was on top of the world. I spent the next few months going on talk shows, meeting with important political figures, and engaging in some hardcore drugs.  The only problem was that we needed Guillermo to add the special final touch to every cookie we packaged, as he was the only one capable of producing the perfect cookie. This did make mass production harder, yes, but the sense of scarcity only made our cookies all the more expensive. But one day, as one of my associates came down to deliver Guillermo his daily meal of beans on bread, we had discovered that he smashed the mirror in his room and used the shards to slash his wrists. He was dead on site. Normally this wouldn't be any of my concern as it was a common occurrence in many of our facilities, but the death of our beloved Guillermo meant that the quality of our cookies would be directly impacted. To make matters worse, the authorities had begun to catch on to our practices.  Apparently Guillermo came from a very rich family, and they had hired a private investigator to track his whereabouts. This ultimately lead them to infiltrate our main factory, where they captured footage of our workers and released the information to the press. The world was too blind to see that there had to be some sacrifices in order to achieve prosperity. They were too foolish to understand that without me, their lives would be meaningless. It did not matter though. In the coming hours, our campus had been breached and many of our workers had been freed. And there I was, barricaded in my office all alone. It gave me time to ponder everything... Did I regret everything I had done in order to reach this point? God no. My name might go down in history as one of treachery, but the truth will always be there. I perfected the meal. I made the lives of the many more enjoyable. Some day they would understand. I took one last look at the empire I had built. They would never take me alive. The secret of the cookie dies with me. To whomever reads this, just know that there is always room for perfection. Even in the most simplest of things, like a cookie.

I've actually played the browser version of this game for well over 1000 hours, its great!  it gets the mix of replayability and fun just right to deserve the Spot as one of the most recognizable clicker games of all time. So it mostly boils down to "is this version worth spending 3-4 bucks on or should i just  play the original with adblocker?" Well, its complicated, you see the original browser version has a javascript console and it just so happens that a lot of the mods and addons for this game were played and loaded through that, also it had pretty accessible cheats to play around with and try some weird combinations with; on the other hand this version is more stable, less laggy, is integrated with steam features, is integrated with the workshop for easier mod loading and works with the browser saves; for example i imported my browser save and thats how i have the game on 94% completion with 40 minutes of steam playtime.  All in all its worth it, if you wanna try something more polished than the browser version and you don't mind the absence of the console, if you REALLY need it you can export your steam save to web, do the console editing with that and then import it back to steam. I have a soft spot for these silly idle clicker games, and usually find them to be pretty enjoyable.  I thought I'd enjoy this one as well, because it's seen as a classic among this genre.  Unfortunately I didn't really like this enough to stick with it for as long as most others.  The big thing that I didn't particularly like about this game was that at the start there are absolutely no offline earnings.  I understand limiting how much offline earnings you can get near the beginning of a game like this, but to have none whatsoever makes it harder for me to get into.  This is less an idle clicker and more of an active clicker that wants you to have the game open at all times to make progress, even if it's just in the background.  You do eventually get upgrades that give you offline earnings, but even then they're very limiting from what I've seen, like the first one only giving 5% earnings for a while when offline, and then going down to .5% if you take too long to check back in.  It seems a bit silly that this is a deal breaker for me, but once I'm past the beginning I just prefer to be able to occasionally open and check in on these games and get some upgrades before moving on to something else, rather than having them open on my computer all the time to make decent progress.  If that doesn't bother you with these kind of games, you'll probably enjoy this one then.

Realistically, there's no need to buy this. Its the exact same as the web version with a few extremely minor extra features that barely make a difference. But by giving Orteil 5 dollars you are supporting the game that singlehandedly revived and popularized the "idle game" genre. (That, and the fact that you can show people how much of a psycho you are by getting all the achievements)  As for a review of the actual game, I think thats almost kind of not necessary since the game is free to play at [url= https://orteil.dashnet.org/cookieclicker/]Orteil's site[/url]. You can basically play as long as you want there to see if it's something you enjoy enough to throw a couple bucks at. If you want my personal two cents, I think its been surpassed by better idle games at this point, but its such an absolute classic that I still put it up top as one of the most enjoyable ones you could possibly play. The flavour and weird minigames added over time really sell the presentation and game feel. I hope that Orteil continues to enjoy making idle games because he's done a few others on his site that are currently in beta but have a lot of promise.   All in all, this game deserves to be paid for, but you can also play it for free if you so desire.

Cookie Clicker is a very addictive idle clicker game where your main goal is to get as many cookies as possible. You are an investor and by clicking, buying upgrades, earning cookies and upgrade your business, you'll get even more cookies. It's very satisfying to see the numbers go up, and being able to buy everything within seconds since you earn cookies like water.  I've played this game many years ago, and I used to be very addicted to it! Its so awesome to see this game on Steam and how it grew through the years, I wish I had saved my previous save file. The game feels nostalgic, addictive and at the same time pointless.  There is a workshop with mods that can help you in the game too, like auto-clickers, optimizers and what so ever. I used to be a person that clicked by hand without any macros, and I know its super dumb but I felt proud of how fast I could click, but then my boyfriend used macros and I saw how fast he went so jealous me started using macros too and then the fun was gone. Apart from using a macro, I was about to install mods again, but it felt like history repeating itself and that feeling sucked out the fun for me it yet again.  Apart from my personal vendetta with the game, it's a decent time killer and fun to play while watching a movie or letting it run while you are away.

You click the cookie. Clicking the cookie facilitates buying buildings that help getting more cookies. Eventually you get upgrades to make those buildings more efficient. Eventually you get a sugar lump that unlocks minigames that also increase cookie productivity. Eventually you call upon magic, the stock market, the art of gardening, and gods to get more cookies. Eventually you research something that makes your unpaid elderly workforce more productive, then begin a series of events that leads to touching powers beyond our comprehension, drowning the world in a deluge of baked goods and chocolate, all in the pursuit of getting more cookies.  The world ends as eldritch abominations walk the earth, personally invited by you on the promise of more cookies. With the world in ruins, you discover you are no longer productive enough to acquire the next tier of upgrades in a reasonable amount of time. You use the giant cookie as the catalyst to bring about your own end, ridding yourself of your mortal shell, and the screen goes dark - but this is not game over. In death your are only given more power to get more cookies at impossible rates. You are brought back to a familiar screen - one giant cookie to click on, a blank middle column, and rows of buildings and upgrades to choose from.  You click the cookie.

Cookie Clicker is miles better than it was back in 2014 when I last played it. So much as been added to it over the years, and it's a very good experience, especially if you like having something to check up on in the background while you do other things. The game is still free on the web, so rather than reading a review to know if you like it, you should go and play it yourself a bit and see. :)  The Steam version only really makes a few tiny tweaks to the original web version, it's really just a nice little way for fans of the game to go and support it's developer, Oritel (which you should). The only features confirmed to be Steam exclusive are the yet-to-be implemented Steam Workshop support and the game's new soundtrack by C418.  As far as idle/incrementer games go, Cookie Clicker falls on the more simplistic side, or so I've been told at least. I've certainly noticed that every so often you run into sort of "progression walls" that you need to overcome by waiting for cookies to build up so you can buy an upgrade, or in the mid-game, ascending after massive amounts of prestige build up so you can buy new heavenly upgrades, especially permaslots for some upgrades. The late-game is spent by waiting for sugar lumps to upgrade buildings (which is very very slow) and/or repeatedly ascending every so often to add to your total prestige. This sort of design is both good and bad depending on who you ask, but for those who don't like being stuck waiting, many of these things can be improved or sped up with mods, which is a totally fine way to play the game. Many mods don't even disable the Steam Achievements, and you can even download a mod that forces them on, if you just want to make some personal tweaks to the way the game progression works. Personally I run the game with a good number of mods that allow me to automate a lot of things, since I find a lot of the fun of Cookie Clicker for me comes from the idling w/ occasional checking-in play-style.  Regardless it's well worth the 5 bucks, and makes for a great gift for friends as well. This was gifted to me for my birthday by my friend, ihaveamac. Thanks for that, buddy.   I could honestly see myself leaving this open for months, maybe years if I had no self control.

Cookie Clicker is damaging to yourself and those around you.  Cookie Clicker is an addiction. Based on my extensive naturalistic observation, I have seen how far a person can and will go in order to keep clicking cookies. This behaviour is very closely related to the behaviour of addicts, supporting my statement about Cookie Clicker being an addiction.  Cookie Clicker is the only thing on the effected person's mind. Even during the short periods where Cookie Clicker is not being played, the addicted individual will talk about Cookie Clicker any chance they get. Unfortunately, many people I know have faced this horrible addiction and I have seen how it takes over their minds. One time, while I was helping an addicted child overcome his problem, another addicted man came and stole the conversation from me turning it into a twisted talk of obsession. There was another time that really stood out in my mind about how Cookie Clicker is always on the effected individual's mind. I was in the car with two addicted individuals and was trying to have a normal, healthy, conversation with one. Sadly, the other person interrupted the conversation to talk about his cookies, and in doing so, he ruined a game that me and the other addicted person have been playing for years. That was truly a soul crushing moment for me.  As the addiction gets worse, the effected person will forgo any form of healthy social interaction to feed his addiction. There have been many times where I would try to enjoy some social time with a person who is addicted to Cookie Clicker, but they will always choose the game over real people. Sometimes, although it is rare, they will participate in social activity, but their thoughts are quickly consumed by cookies and it shows in their choice of conversation.  Like any addiction, the Cookie Clicker addiction is damaging to those who care for the addicted individual. The addiction will cause those who care for the effected person to feel guilty. The addicted person's family may feel responsible for that person's addiction. They will question how they have allowed them to develop an addiction, or perhaps they fought hard to help the addicted individual but were not able to help. Regardless of the circumstances, those who are close to the addicted individual will carry guilt and blame themselves to a certain extent.  As I mentioned earlier, I know people that are effected by this horrid game. I have seen others try to explain to them how damaging a simple game could be but they refuse to listen, and to some extent, those people blame themselves for not trying hard enough and letting them get sucked into this dark place. Another way it could affect those around the effected person is by them downplaying the problem. Like any addiction, people close to the person could just live in denial about the effected person's problem. They might make excuses for the person's behaviour or downplay the problem. They could also be scared about addressing the issue, worried about the possible future for the person, so they choose to ignore it instead of dealing with it.  At first I thought that this Cookie Clicker was a simple, although completely boring, game. Oh how wrong I was. The game slowly consumes the players, like a child eating cookies. I thought it was just going to be another game that people would quickly get bored of or forget about a few days later, and because of these thoughts, the Cookie Clicker addiction had time to fully manifest itself in their minds, since no one was trying to stop them. Another way it damages those around the addicted person, is that the addiction controls their mind. When people are addicted to something their whole life revolves around the addiction. It consumes their mind turning them into a different person, which is scary to those around them. Instead of the person seeing you as someone who cares for them, they will only see you as someone who is getting in the way of the only thing they care about, Cookie Clicker. You can try all you want to help the person get over this Cookie Clicker, but they won't see it that way. You could turn the computer off, but instead of the nice person you knew and cared for they will turn into some monster, screaming at you for making them lose their precious cookies. They are no longer the person you cared for.  Playing Cookie Clicker even just once is dangerous. Like any addictive thing, it may take only one time to become addicted. Cookie Clicker has just enough stuff for someone to keep on "playing" right from the beginning. At first you start with nothing, but as you continue clicking you gather enough cookies for upgrades, which make it so you can get more cookies faster, making you repeat an endless cycle of pain.  Cookie Clicker also has achievements for you to get, which keeps you hooked on the game. Not only does it have the upgrades that were mentioned earlier, but it also has achievements. Some of these achievement titles prove that the creators of the game are well aware that it's an addiction by having the achievement titles relate to drug use. One achievement is "So baked right now", another is "Overdose", and these sayings clearly show the relations to drug use.  Even if you manage to beat this addiction there is always the possibility of having a relapse. Unfortunately, no one I know has overcome this problem, but based on my knowledge of addictions, it's a very real possibility that they could suffer from a relapse. Relapses are a miserable part of addiction, even after you overcome the problem there is still a chance it could come back at any time. Possibly because of stress, negative emotions, really strong cravings, or being around things that remind you of Cookie Clicker. It is very damaging to your life and you might have to avoid cookies for the rest of your life unless you want to relapse. So you shouldn't play the game, even just once.  By now you should realize how dangerous this so called "game" is and the harmful effects it has on not only the player, but also those who care for the player. I truly hope that this paper will open people's eyes about this so called game, and that anyone who reads this won't let anyone they care for get sucked into this Cookie Clicker.
