Don't let the short run time on Steam fool you: I was playing the browser version of this game many years ago and saved my file from there and brought it over to Steam.   That allowed me to get a large number of achievements immediately and it was making cookies the entire time, so the amount I started the Steam version with was intense.  There isn't much to say about this game except that for as simple a concept as it is (to make more cookies by endlessly clicking on that one big cookie), there is a bit of depth for upgrading things, buying and selling when need be, and also dealing with the grandmas and the oddness that can happen when they are not appeased.  More than a "time waster", this game can be a lot of fun when you don't have a ton to do at the moment.  The music is pleasant and fun and the graphics are nice enough.

This is the granddaddy of all idle games. There were some before it, like Progress Quest, but this is the first one to really make a splash.  So what do you do? You click on a cookie for a while. After a bit, you buy things to click for you. Ideally for most of the game, you should be doing relatively little actual clicking. The core gameplay loop is watching your cookies go up, then using those cookies to build things to make your cookies go up ever faster. That's it. Bigger and bigger numbers of cookies. Eventually you reset the game with a fat bonus to cookies per second and do it all over again, but even faster.
THE idle game

This is a good idle game, but it's an idle game. The game runs well, has a nice aesthetic and a good sense of humour, and it feels very satisfying to buy upgrades and to rapidly gain cookies. Expect to spend a lot of time mindlessly clicking though, and don't be surprised if you end up staring blankly at the cookies pouring down, wondering what you're doing with your life.  It's also important to consider that this game [b]will[/b] shorten the length of your mouse. Despite the judgement you might get online if you admit to doing so, don't be afraid to use macros or even auto clickers to play this game. There's nothing wrong with playing how you want to play and it definitely isn't worth wearing out or breaking your mouse just to play this game "the right way".  You probably already know if this is a game for you. If you don't like idle games or the idea of "big number get bigger" doesn't interest you, then avoid this game. If that sounds like it's right up your alley though, then you'll probably enjoy this game.

[H1]Cookie Clicker at the beginning:[/h1] "Click 15 times for a cursor."  [H1]Cookie Clicker at the end:[/h1] "Every part of life is perverted to serve the purpose of the economy, nothing is too sacred to be sacrificed upon its altar. And for what? What's the point of a massive global economy if it fails to protect the elderly and the vulnerable? Even those with the most cookies don't really benefit from the system. Once you're past a certain level of wealth, you can never spend that many cookies. And it's not like the game ever ends, you can never win Cookie Clicker. You just keep making cookies until you stop or die, you're just hoarding cookies for its own sake. It's not really about the cookies - it's about the journey ,the accumulation ,getting more."  -10/10-

Where do I even start! Not only did they turn this flash game into a masterpiece by adding way more content, but they made it so that every achievement in game.... is a steam achievement. That's 500+ achievements by just playing the game, but not only are there your main achievements, but a ton of secret ones too. On top of that, the game has so much content that you will never get bored, because of the feature that you have to unlock offline earnings. There are hundreds of upgrades and tons of different things you can buy to make you cookies per second, and even better all the upgrades and things that make you cookies, are super balanced and you wont be overpowered or under-powered when spending a lot of cookies. The upgrades are not only good for making cookies, but will give you a sense of bliss. All of the unlock-able cookie making ??? are so pleasureful to see and all the sprites of them are adorable in a way, with its retro but somewhat modern looks. This game also has a new music set by C418..... The music corporation that made Minecraft music discs. The music in game is relaxing but exciting in a way. It is a great atmosphere for this game because your clicking a cookie, and then listening to music that you will never get bored of. When you get further into the game you can unlock mini games, that don't only make you cookies but you can have an extra bump of fun. Some mini games include a stock market and having your own farm, to casting spells at your own risk and many more. Now that this game is also getting updated frequently, that also means that the graphics will be improving as hardware increases in modern day society. All of this content and more and the game only costs $5, that is a great cost for a game you could spend hundreds of hours on. This game is a 10/10 for people that like retro clicker games, awesome atmosphere, and just something that you will get tons of hours in for your money.

I've been a  Cookie Clicker fan for years now. I've 100%'d the game multiple times through the years. I can't even fathom how much time I've lost to this game.  [h1]The Good[/h1] Simple gameplay loop that's fun and engaging. Defined the idle/incremental genre's popularity spike. It wasn't the first, and certainly is standing on the shoulder's of giants, but it brought the genre to life. Cookie Clicker has hours and hours of engaging content, with WAY more passive content. Take your time to enjoy the sinister, the crazy, and the quirky. Read that flavor text. Chase those achievements. Bake those cookies.  [h1]The Bad[/h1] I have nothing about this game I dislike. Legit nothing. I love it. Maybe it's too good. Maybe that's the bad.  [h1]Overall[/h1] If you don't want to pay $5 [url=https://orteil.dashnet.org/cookieclicker/]go play the game online free[/url]. Otherwise, support Orteil  (the baker of this fine cookie) and get it on Steam while enjoying the optional ambient music made by C418.

Cookie Clicker has been the best idle game in the game from the day it launched over a decade ago. I don't know if that's controversial or not, but I believe it wholeheartedly, and I've played tons of idle games!  Don't let my time played on Steam fool you, I've invested hundreds of hours in Cookie Clicker's web version over the years, and the stuffed added to the Steam release is huge for me. With a wonderful soundtrack from C418, Steam achievements, and cloud saves, buying Cookie Clicker on Steam is a no-brainer for anyone who enjoys the idle genre.

I've played this game since i was 13 years old in the web version and it has been in my life ever since. I remember leaving my computer on during the night just to get more cookies and waking up to see the progress and it felt, and still feels, really satisfying.  Since then the game had [b] MANY [/b] updates and [b] MANY [/b] additions to it's gameplay, ranging from new minigames to new cookie mechanics, now with steam it has cloud saving (i had to use text files on drive to backup) and the fricking music from c418, the creator of some of the most iconic minecraft musics, this alone just doubles my nostalgy. Bringing it to steam just means it won't stop there and i'm looking foward to see what's coming.  Seriously, if this game has any discount, wait for it to be full price again to buy it, it's so worth it you will feel bad later if you don't and believe me when i say: It isn't just a normal incremental clicker game. It is [spoiler] Cookie Clicker. [/spoiler]

No, not just a great game, the GREATEST damn game in the WORLD. This game is the game that started the idle game genre and must be respected with honor. This game has the most work put into it making it the BEST clicker game. This game has you coming back to it to check your cookies, pop wrinklers, buy upgrades/building. This game is very enjoyable as you start buying the more expensive buildings/upgrades and watching your CPS increase. Gaining achievements is really fun as you need to collect them for milk which increases your CPS by a big amount with cat upgrades. The grandmapocalypse caused by grandmas working at a bingo/ research center, who the hell even comes up with this shit. That's right Orteil the man from Europe (and someone else). They been updating this game for a WHOLE 10 YEARS, always adding more content every time. The mini games that you unlock with sugar lumps and really great additions to this game, adding a garden, Pantheon, Grimoire, Stock Market, and soon a dungeon system for the mines. These all add something to the game that all have effects too your CPS. Give this game a try and play it. Play it for 30 minutes and see how much this game takes from you, the game where you click the cookie.

Okay. So, this game is the same as the web version, both of which will receive the same updates. Deciding to purchase the steam version is mainly just to support the developers (and to get those steam achievements ;D). Plus, you get a easily accessible downloadable version of the game. By using the steam version, we also get access to cloud saving which is a god send of course! There is also a mods folder provided with the game meaning that there should be some cool workshop mods in the future. Plus, I mean the new C418 background music is pretty sweet! I'd definitely recommend picking this up for a few bucks to give back to the hard working developers and to have some nostalgic fun!

Cookie Clicker is the best game of its genre. It's an idle game where you make cookies. Simple as that. It was made in 2013 as a browser game (technically it still is, as the Steam version just run into a webview) and it's still being updated today.   The game can be played for free on the official webpage, or you could just support the developer and play the Steam version, it's only 4€ which I think it's pretty fair.

In love with this stupid cookie game

[b]Here we go again...[/b]  It's the original cookie clicker from 2013 but updated with a chip-ton of content and improvements over the years. It's also up to date with the web version (that will update along side it, wow) so the difference here is paying $5 for it. I find it funny that the dev for Clicker Heroes is publishing the idle defying game too, what a world.  However, you'll be able to play offline, gain cloud saving, and listen to the new and exclusive music by C418 for this version! The Minecraft composer guy who also made some great sounding music too (listen to his other albums other than the minecraft ones, they are neat)! And with workshop support coming in the future? Woah.  So yeah, if you want to actually buy this game this time around from 2013 all spruced up with the benefits from steam, get this! It supports the developer of this game which is finally deserved from all the free work they did over all of this time.

Ever since I wee Lad sucking on my mother's teet, I was a big Cookie Clicker fan. You could even say I was the biggest of Cookie Clicker fans. some may that is because of my EXTREEEMLY morbid obesity, but I think it's due to my expansive collection of Cookie Clicker memorabilia. Now after being the biggest Cookie Clicker enjoyer for my entire long lasting lifetime,(I am 400) I can say this game is the sole deliverer of joy in my life, and without it I would have been dead a long long time ago. So yes Cookie Clicker may in fact be the best game ever to be released on Steam, and maybe even the best game of all time simply because of the fact that I get massive erection at the sight of the cookie clicker grandma. This game cured my erectile dysfunction (as my doctor said my penis puts the dys in erectile dysfunction), actually this game worsened my erectile dysfunction as I can only get it on at the sight of Cookie Clicker Grandma Deep within the cores and valves of my pleasure center. I don't think you understand. My balls used to be massive before this game, but as my doctor said before he got a restraining order, "The best way to describe your balls is an edited version of the Poem "Harlem" by Langston Hughes,  "What happens to your balls deferred?         Do they dry up        like raisins in the sun?        Or fester like sores—        And then run?        Do they stink like rotten meats?        Or crust and sugar over—        like syrupy sweets?         Maybe they just sags        like a heavy load         Or do they explode?"'  10/10 I Recommend it and I would and and arm playing again.

I sold a Grandma. Maybe, this is one of the reasons why I am facing such depression and anxiety.  Someone told me by making a confession will set my spirit free. I agree with that and I really hope my confession will set my spirit free, out of the misery. Therefore, I would like to write my stories as a confession.  It was about a Grandma that I didn't need in my bakery anymore. She was a nice and funny lady that everyone loved, her name was Nana. She was starting to get very old and I had to get her out of the bakery. I discovered the other day that there is a steam achievement that I need to sell a grandma for. I sold Nana for the achievement.  There is no point in writing such a story because not many people will read it. I would like a lot of people to read it and comment their opinions about what I did. I would like to know what other people think of what I did to poor Nana.  I believe it will help me find out the truth much better whether I was a victim or monster.  First, I would like to write my story on my Facebook; but I don’t know how it works. I mean I don’t have many friends or many connections, so from my understanding it will not be read by many people, right?  Please before you start your own bakery listen to me. Grandmas are awesome and you should not sell them for the steam achievement.

This game is over the charts of the games I have played!  There are some stuff you would understand and things you cannot.  There are things that you can click, you can click on the giant cookie, then you would get some build some stuff to start your own life, then there are golden cookies, you click them, you get a surprise, but when there are red cookies, they give out good thing and sometimes bad things.   And finally, fortunes.   Every time you click on the cookie, your fortunes expands. if you click on it, it will ask you if you want to expand.   To my opinion, do not expand yet you can expand when you have a lot of fortunes.  And what I heard, if you played it for an entire month, you would get a mod!  If you want this mod, you have to download it to get it.  So when you have it, it will do clicking for you, it would get golden cookies for you, it will raise your fortune.  Everyone, if you have seen this review, you have to bake your own legacy!

Good game with a lot of history and very pretty art. The games been free for years so its quality has been proven and if you want to prove it yourself you can literally just go to the Cookie Clicker website instead.  Why would someone want the Steam version over the free browser version? Quality of life. With the Steam version of Cookie Clicker you're allowed to have cloud saves, Steam recording your in-game achievements, controller support (if you really feel like playing a clicker with a controller), etc. The UI is also slightly different but not really [i] that [/i] different. Oh yeah, and there's the sublime OST that comes with the Steam version. (I mean I guess you could just play the OST on YouTube for free, but it repeats smoother in Steam. Again, quality of life is the main reason for purchase here.)  But I have one major complaint with the game still. Why does a browser game running on Electron not have native support for macOS or Linux???

It all started a few years ago, when I first found out about the Indie game about making cookies... it seemed like an interesting and silly game to waste some of my time, nothing could possibly go wrong... oh how young and naive I was.   The first few days were rather simple, I click, I receive cookies and I buy a building that gives me cookies. I let the buildings give me cookies while I go on about my business.   But then as the day passed, the numbers went up. And as the numbers went up, I started to get more and more absorbed in the cookie business. Every time my Cookies Per Second increased, so did my levels of dopamine. It was too late for me to quit, I had to make more cookies.   I clicked for hours at a time, I gave up on everything else I had. I had to buy 17 new mice because they couldn't endure the multiple hours of intense clicking. But I didn't care, my Cookies Per second were still increasing.   I completely stopped doing anything that didn't help me click cookies, my healthy deteriorated faster than Greece's economy. But I didn't care, my Cookies Per second were still increasing.  I stopped going to work, I no longer had any source of income. Food was slowly running out. But I didn't care, my Cookies Per second were still increasing.   But suddenly, everything went dark. The cookies were no longer there, there was nothing but a black screen. The electricity went out as I had no money to pay for the electricity bills. I sat and stared at the screen as I realized what I had done. As I realized that this was all meaningless, I was making virtual cookies.   I then went into rehab, hesitant however as I was not sure of where that would lead me. I thankfully got out of that mess I was in, I was finally free. I got back on my feet again, found a great job that provided me with a great source of income, I rebuilt my life.  A week or so ago I was searching the steam store as usual, searching for a new game to pass a few moments of my time while I relax after my return from work. And I saw it. Cookie Clicker, on the front page. I froze, I couldn't believe it. I couldn't control myself, I had to buy the game. I just couldn't resist it. Seeing the new updates... the new ways to make cookies... it was the most irresistible offer I had ever gotten. I instantly bought the game.  I am now here, making cookies non-stop. The numbers are going higher by the seconds, I am no longer in the Cookie business, I am in the Empire Business.  I got fired from my job due to my recent absences. I have the carpal tunnel syndrome and I am in severe pain. But I don't care, my Cookies Per second are still increasing.

[h1] What is Cookie Clicker? [/h1] The name says it all! Cookie Clicker is an iconic idle clicker game, in which you click a cookie to earn, well, cookies! Those cookies are then used on buildings and upgrades to help make even more of them, rinse and repeat. If you're familiar with how idle games work, even if you've never played Cookie Clicker, you'll fit right in with no problems.  [h1] Pacing [/h1] The gameplay of Cookie Clicker is well paced, with early game becoming much quicker as you begin to ascend and earn heavenly upgrades. In late game, the grinding maintains a nice speed, made better with the ability to ascend at any time to earn a permanent multiplier on your Cookies Per Second (in the form of a percentage boost).  [h1] Graphics [/h1] If you haven't seen anything about the game, the visuals provide a nice and suitiable backdrop, with the ability to turn off the more fancy effects if you wish to. With all of them enabled, the game looks clear and plays incredibly smoothly, with solid 60 FPS, so you can see all your cookies rack up with no drops in the frames. To go with this, every achievement has it's own unique image to accompany it, and many of them are accompanied by quirky names and even the occasional reference to a game or meme! A very nice touch.  [h1] Why this version? [/h1] Some may argue that you can play the browser version of this game for free, but for the cheap price, this version of the game is well worth the cost. The soundtrack, handcrafted by none other than C418, (y'know, the legend who made the soundtrack to Minecraft!) provides a relaxing and immersive experience. With achievement support, the grinding you'll perform is also acknowledged, something that isn't present in the browser version of the game.  [h1] Summary [/h1] Overall, Cookie Clicker on Steam is an incredible experience for fans of the game, and is more than welcoming to those wishing to give the game a try for the first time. Whether you're a long time cookie entrepreneur, or a brand new baker, you'll find enjoyment out of this version of the hit clicker game.

Ingredients for 12 cookies:  ½ cup granulated sugar (100 g) ¾ cup brown sugar (165 g), packed 1 teaspoon salt ½ cup unsalted butter (115 g), melted 1 egg 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 1 ¼ cups all-purpose flour (155 g) ½ teaspoon baking soda 4 oz milk or semi-sweet chocolate chunks (110 g) 4 oz dark chocolate chunk (110 g), or your preference   Method: In a large bowl, whisk together the sugars, salt, and butter until a paste forms with no lumps. Whisk in the egg and vanilla, beating until light ribbons fall off the whisk and remain for a short while before falling back into the mixture. Sift in the flour and baking soda, then fold the mixture with a spatula (Be careful not to overmix, which would cause the gluten in the flour to toughen resulting in cakier cookies). Fold in the chocolate chunks, then chill the dough for at least 30 minutes. For a more intense toffee-like flavor and deeper color, chill the dough overnight. The longer the dough rests, the more complex its flavor will be. Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Scoop the dough with an ice-cream scoop onto a parchment paper-lined baking sheet, leaving at least 4 inches (10 cm) of space between cookies and 2 inches (5 cm) of space from the edges of the pan so that the cookies can spread evenly. Bake for 12-15 minutes, or until the edges have started to barely brown. Cool completely before serving. Enjoy!   Refrencing: cookie recipe from https://tasty.co/recipe/the-best-chewy-chocolate-chip-cookies    :)

AN OVERCOMPLICATED COOKIE CLICKER REVIEW  Cookie Clicker is an amazing game. I started playing a long time ago and when I heard there was a Steam version coming I bought it as fast as I could.   From the gameplay perspective this game might feel a little boring at first, but that's one of the tropes of Cookie Clicker: It teaches you patience. The game is very well balanced, so at first you don't get overwhelmed with features and new things come in at a steady rate, so you never get bored.  So what genre is Cookie Clicker you might ask? Well, you may think of it as a "clicker" game, but that's only scratching the surface. In reality it's a business/strategy game. "But how is it a strategy game?" You might ask. Well, in the late game there is a bunch of ways to make cookies and you need strategy for in which one to invest in, that's also how the business element works.   Are the graphics good? Yes  Is the soundtrack good? Yes (that's actually one of the things added with the Steam release). The soundtrack is made by C418, who also created the soundtrack for the pretty popular game Minecraft.  Is the gameplay good? It's exquisite  About the lore: Cookie Clicker provides a big philosophical insight into what makes capitalism work and where it fails. For some it can be an uplifting message - anyone can achieve anything. Others interpret it as a commentary to how capitalism destroys society. Personally I think it's a game about food.  There are many jokes and popculture references thrown into the game to brighten the mood. But there are also horror elements as well. Cookie Clicker really provides a bit of everything.  The difficulty of the game is determined by how far you want to go and by your patience. The hardest achievements may require a lot of grinding, but for a casual player that shouldn't be a problem.  Overall I think you should definitely buy Cookie Clicker, you'll support the developer and you'll for sure have an amazing time.

It's Cookie Clicker. On Steam. With music, and achievements integration, and mods. The free web version remains unchanged and will receive the same core gameplay updates.  But now we also have a Steam version with a few bonus features.  Buy this if: - You want to support the developer and play without ads. - You'd like an (excellent) soundtrack by C418 to go with the game. - You want Steam achievement integration to share how much of your life you've wasted.  Don't buy this if: - You're expecting a remake. It's the same JavaScript game, launched through Steam with a few bonuses. - You have no idea what Cookie Clicker is. Play the free web game first to see if you like it. - You don't think the additional features are worth $5 of your money over the free version.

Great math game. Honestly if you love math, you will love this game. It is more fun for me when I manually do all of the calculations in my head to see which upgrade will give me the most significant increase in cookie output. Before I started playing I had no educational degrees, but after sending some footage of my live-stream gameplay to Harvard University they just gave me an honorary PHD in Calculus.   10/10, would click again.   -------------------------------------  Seriously, though, if for some reason you are looking at reviews for an actual reason to play the game, I will give them to you:  There is a TON of content. Even if you use an auto-clicker, you will find yourself coming back every minute, if not hour, or day, to check how many cookies you've earned and what upgrades you have.  This has the same addiction as a mobile game but there is no paid currency, once you pay for the game THAT'S IT, no DLC, no hidden things, no "pay $50 to get 5,000,000 cookies!". You play the game, and that's how you earn currency.  I have been following this pet prokect from Orteil for many years since its inception, and it is obvious that they've put A LOT of love and care into this game.  I am really looking forward to this Steam release and seeing what the modding community comes up with!  This game looks basic on the outside, but the longer your play the more features you unlock and there is a lot going on and a lot to play with!  For the amount of content in this $5, you'd be stupid not to buy. It has more hours of content than some $60 AAA games...

Surprisingly a lot of content for an idle clicker game. Its a silly, casual game with humor in it. Once you get further into the game instead of just saving up cookies to buy upgrades, you can unlock "mini games," which can help you get cookies (aka your money) faster. You eventually ascend, which means you start completely over, but gain CpS (cookies per second) for every prestige level you gained. You slowly gain prestige levels just from playing. When you ascend you're heavenly shards equal to your prestige level. You can use those shards to buy permanent upgrades, including ones to keep collecting cookies for days even when the game isn't open. Theres lots of upgrades, bad things that can happen, like various debuffs, little alien things that eat away at your cookies, various holiday events, which you can trigger at will via heavenly shard upgrades, and more. It has a ton of achievements, and the end game seems to become about just collecting all achievements. You can import save files from other people and import mods, like an autoclicker and auto buy mods. This is perfectly fine, and not hacking, as theres a built in feature just for doing so. Theres even a hidden achievement for a certain "cheat." Decent casual game, nothing too crazy, but its a good time waster. I let it run in the background while I play other games.

Cookie Clicker is one of the best stress relievers I've ever experienced, and serves as the forerunner and standard-setter for all other idle games. It has a sense of satisfaction in its progression matched only by games far more mechanically complex than it. There is always something small to improve, which branches out into this incredible spider web of options to pursue as you adjust your strategies dynamically to maximise your output, in a way that never overwhelms the player. It also has minigames which add new incentives and concepts to the game that are themselves deeply addicting. However, it never abuses this addictiveness into exploiting the player through microtransactions, a testament to the developer's dedication to making the experience as pure as possible. I cannot recommend it enough.  I have played the game extensively on the browser platform (see my imported achievements), both as a hands-on experience and as a backburner idle game. For the amount of enjoyment I've gotten out of it, the price is incredible. While I eventually get bored of the game after a while, it pops back in my mind a year or so later, and takes over my life all over again. There's nothing quite like it, and it deserves genuine respect for what it accomplishes.

Look, I have fond memories of the browser version as much as the next person, and I think Orteil getting some money for his work producing... effectively the entire idle game genre (if it wasn't the original idle game, Cookie Clicker definitely was the populariser) is good, actually (especially as paying less than a price of cookie for a downloadable version is about the least evil way of going about earning said money) but... Cookie Clicker is just kind of soul destroying to actually play (and I swear the progression curve is way less generous now which intensifies the issue by requiring longer play times to reach, e.g., the endgame grandmapocalypse, but I am not reinstalling to check the patch notes for balance changes or whatever because... no no that does not seem like a good idea for me).   And that is kind of a big problem because we only have so much time on this Earth and I don't think clicking a picture of a cookie while continually monitoring a fictional stock market is a good way to spend it?   Okay, you could say this point about pointlessness about pretty much any game, but Cookie Clicker is a game that wears the contradictions of video gaming on its sleeve (and so renders them particularly sharp) and while that does make it genuinely interesting from an artistic and satirical standpoint, it does still not make the actual experience of playing it good or healthy - indeed the feeling of compulsion I have to do something so openly and honestly pointless is probably actively unhealthy! (there's a reason I uninstalled after a few days!) - and I kind of have to base a recommendation of whether you should actually play this game on that.  tl;dr As much as a game about massively overproducing cookies being bad for you is kind of fitting... it is still kind of bad for you so maybe don't play it? Like eating a ton of actual cookies might straight up be better for you (or at the very least less bad), in addition to being more enjoyable        .... ... ... ... ... Okay, also, as a petty point, I swear the performance I've experienced is less than ideal. My machine does default to using the integrated GPU rather than the dedicated... but this does not feel like a game that should end up using basically all of said integrated GPU and making my computer straight up sound like a plane taking off at times, even with all the fancy bits turned off? Of course, this may be semi-inherent in Electron, based off my vague memories of using the Atom text editor back when that first came out, but I'm not sure and it is kind of a problem: as much as Cookie Clicker feels like it ought to be able to run on very low end machines (there's low inherent graphics requirements, but I guess the cookie counter updating continually might be an issue? But I am getting way way off topic and into semi-informed (at best) speculation for an aside at the end of a review on Steam here), I have no idea whether it actually will run for more than 10 seconds without something literally melting or whatever.  Now, to be clear, the performance improving massively would not change my review at all, because the issues I have are baked into the structure and nature of the game (pun not originally intended) but, hey, it's a point that might save someone from losing several hours of their life to this thing and it's worth bringing up just generally.

Cookie Clicker was the first of its kind and the genre-definer, but the game doesn't hold up on its own.   I know that it's a clicker, and I played it years ago before it came to Steam, but I just can't feel entertained enough to keep clicking or playing. Seeing numbers go up makes you feel excited, but as soon as you stall it feels really disheartening to be forced to leave your computer running all throughout the night just to make progress in the game.  There's many basic features that should be available from the very moment you start playing, but they are locked behind upgrades that you'll only be able to unlock after ascending. Some even after ascending multiple times, which takes way too much grind to achieve.  The market minigame feels kind of pointless, and getting more wizard towers to get more mana is also pointless because mana costs scale with the towers you own. You're expected to sell them in order to get another shot at it, but not telling the player how to do it at all feels like a problem, not to mention getting the quantity right. It's counter-intuitive to sell anything at all because you crimp your cookie production, even when you have buffs like the idol that boosts your production after selling buildings.  The music is nice, but design-wise the game is pretty bad. I wouldn't recommend buying it if it's not on sale. Alternatively you could just play the web version which is free.

If you've ever played a clicker or idle game before, then you should know what to expect from [i]Cookie Clicker[/i]. At its core, it's a game about watching a number get bigger, and occasionally shrinking that number for the benefit of making it grow back faster.  The reason why people love this game so much, I think, has to do with its jovial personality and bizarre sense of humor that gets increasingly surreal as it goes along. Plus it utilizes all the right Skinner box tactics to keep you playing [i]just for five more minutes, I swear, just five more minutes and then it's off to bed, right after this next upgrade...[/i]  If you're looking for a decent time-waster to leave running in the background while you do other things, you can't go wrong with [i]Cookie Clicker[/i].

I wake up, my PC has been on the last 14 days, Cookie Clicker is still running so it's no problem, electricity fees aren't that expensive anyway. I buy the upgrades and click the cookie. I feel a rush of dopamine.  I open the grimoire, time to cast some spells. I summon a Golden Cookie, it's a Click Frenzy, I've never been more prepared in my life. I click the cookie. Suddenly, my mouse button breaks, it's just the 6th, I have 8 more in the drawer. No problem. I click the cookie.  My girlfriend calls me, she wants to hang out, so annoying. I tell her that I'm clicking the cookie, she complains that I don't give her enough attention. What a drama queen, it's has been only 2 months without contact. I broke with her in the moment, and click the cookie.  7 hours later, my mom enters the basement, and shows me job offers. I look at her with disgust. As if jobs give something valuable, all I need is to click the cookie.  It's 2 am when suddenly the game crashes, no worries, I'll just start it again. But something terrible happened. My save is gone. I stay still, staring at the screen. 0 cookies. This can't be real.  I lock the door and grab a rope, life isn't worth living anymore.

This is supposed to be an idler. Granted, I'm not terribly far in, but the early gameplay is fairly painful. No early offline progress means that even if you want to slowly progress to an offline play strat, you have to start with online. Numbers grow with some apparent meaning, but feels stagnant and hopeless early on, even for an Idler. Maybe an ascention or two will feel nicer, but the only things to differentiate this from other Idlers is cutesie (but still minimal) pictures and animation, and a cookie-themed marquee of useless cookie-world imaginings running along the top of the screen.  I wouldn't say it's heavy on CPU (best I can tell), but it's not worth its weight at the moment, prior to first ascention, 9 hours of play, much of it non-idle (a ton of power to be had non-idle, yet still not enough to feel impactful). That's a long while for basically no gameplay to speak of.  I get the feeling this older (I think?) title sparked a thing or two in the Idle genre on release (somehow I avoided this title), but others adapted and excelled over this one.

This game makes for a pretty good clicker but a terrible idler. I suppose it's called Cookie Clicker and not Idle Cookies for a reason.   The reason why is that progression in this game is extremely slow, especially at the start, unless you're constantly paying attention to it and clicking the golden cookies that appear every two minute or so on the screen.   Unlike in many other similar games where you can sorta choose between the active and the passive route, in this one the only way to get any semblance of progress at all is through big combos, which, while they are quite satisfying when you pull them off, are almost entirely reliant on RNG, which can make for a very frustrating experience if you're not the gambling type.  So this game takes up a lot of your time and attention, but it's not like it offers anything riveting in return, and most of the time you'll just find yourself blankly staring at the screen waiting for something to happen, occasionally spamming your left click, and the rest of the time it'll be in the back of your mind, distracting you from your other activities, but not in a good way.  The fact that there isn't even any offline progress until you unlock it through the ascension mechanic, and even then it's only a pitiful fraction of what you'd make with the game open, that was the nail in the coffin. To me the whole point of this kind of game is that comforting feeling of having something running in the background, progressing without needing input, and never feeling obligated to check back on it but being happy to do so because I'll know I'll be rewarded for my patience. I didn't find that with this game. It was fun for a few hours, maybe from the nostalgia factor as I remember playing this on browser many years ago, but it got old pretty quick.  As for the fact this game isn't free-to-play unlike most clicker/idlers, that's actually one of the few positives for me, as in this case it means no tantalizing micro-transactions. Its price is very cheap anyways... However if you value your time, I'd stay away from this one as it'll eat up a lot more of it than it ought to.

This game saved my life.  I am 69.  My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.  When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.  After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.  Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.  After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.  Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.  I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.  Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.  Thank you.

I wanted to play the game that inspired Clicker Heroes, one of my favorite ide/clicker games, so when this came to Steam I decided to give it a try. I'm actually not a big fan of cookies IRL, so the cookie theme got old very fast. It also involves a bit more active micromanaging then I prefer. I work FT and attend grad school, so I like to have idle games in the background that don't require a lot of my time.   With this game you can just let it run in the background, but if you're not actively farming seeds and casting spells, then you're missing out on huge amounts of CPS which makes it not enjoyable for me. I like incremental games that have viable idle or hybrid builds, and I'm not sure if that is available in the endgame or not, but I'm really not willing to put in the thousands of hours to find out. I imagine most people that like idle/clickers might enjoy this game, but it's not for me.

What does it mean to beat something? Do you beat it when you get all the achievements? When you unlock all the upgrades? When you get all the buildings? When you learn everything the game has to offer? What is the meaning of completing a game, or beating it? Something I contemplated myself, it's similar to finding what the meaning of life is. As time is made up of our life, what meaning is it to dedicate time to something?   I shall give you an example as I found the answer for myself, but you may find a different one. No answers are wrong. A subjective question can only have a subjective answer, and subjective answers are never wrong.  I played this game with the intent to help me clarify my reasoning. At first, I intended to get all the buildings, all the achievements, then I decided getting all the achievements was just far too much. This game is like a journey within yourself to find the inner meaning within the cookies.  I think what I play is for that journey. Nothing more. I don't care to have all the cookies, all the achievements, all the buildings. I played this game for the journey toward the cookies alone. I enjoyed the journey. The mechanics, the clicking, the buildings, the upgrades, maximizing cookie production, etc. It is the very essence of the game I came for, and I was not disappointed. I used to play games to be better, the best, but I didn't do this game for that. I came into this game to play it as a joke, but I left enlightened and much happier with my life and the choices I made. Thank you, cookie clicker.

A game which predominantly does not progress idly, yet has larger and more frequent progression walls than most of that genre. The game is chock full of ways to slow you down and encourage you to leave it on, yet it eats up resources (RAM) and is infuriatingly slow without active clicking and resource management.  Strongly do not recommend, and that's before getting into cloud/save issues. If you want a good idle/clicker, there are plenty out there(Melvor, Clickocalypse, Adventure Capitalist, The Longing). Alternatively, you can wear out the humorous gimmick of this one by playing the free browser version and reading the funny notifications and going "lol cookie" once or twice before turning it off.

It's a classic, yes. I played the heck out of it years ago, and I loved it. But since its inception dozens, if not hundreds of incremental clicker/idle games followed. I played many of them. Idle Slayer, Clicker Heroes, Venture Communist/Capitalist, that Evolution game turning into The Matrix, all parts of Candy Box, I don't know. I'm an office worker, of course I know these games. And now, after eight years, it's very hard to say, but  [b]Cookie Clicker fails at everything good.[/b]  Okay, let's start.  [h1]The Good[/h1]  It's a classic. Mmh.. What else?  [h1]The Bad[/h1]  First: No idle income. Yes, you read that right. You don't get anything from turning the game off and going to your day job. You could let it running, sure, but seriously, what year are we? On top of that the developer added a handful of minigames that let you wait for a number of minutes, like ten or twenty, but demand your interaction or else the reward necessary to progress in the game is lost. Essentially the game was turned from an idle game into a waiting game. Great job?  Second: The progression mechanic. Of course you need to reset to get an amount of Other Currency[tm] and maybe get an advantage for the next incarnation, like in all incremental games. Unfortunately it is never communicated [i]when[/i] to reset. Do I wait until I get to the last building or do I reset before? Coupled with the nonexisting idle mechanic this is an absolute failure. In addition the devs added [i]another[/i] currency that you can use to level up in between without resetting, and to use with the minigames, so it demands even more interaction, but also more waiting, because this currency regenerates [i]once[/i] ([b]1⨯!![/b]) per day. It is tedious.  Third: The minigames, and the overall game. Yes, these deserve a seperate point. Simply: Why? What is this? Why should I use these? There is a garden. This garden is supposed to grow plants, from random mutations. Some of these mutations have a random chance of 0.1% per tick. Each tick is between 3 and 15 minutes. You start with a plot of 4, and to get a maximum plot you need to wait 55 days. In addition to the weeks or months you wait to get all these plant mutations. And if you miss the right time to harvest your plants and possible mutations, its gone. No stepping back, no idle harvesting, no one to pay attention. You start from anew.  And that is [b]ONE[/b] of these minigames! I have just one question: Why? To slow down the next step or the end of the game? Where's the fun in that?  [h1]The Ugly[/h1]  That part pains me the most. I love Minecraft, okay, I admit it. I love the soundtrack by C418. I bought his Bandcamp discography, I follow him on Twitter, but …  … after ten repeats his tune sucks. Sorry. I said it. Put it away, turn it off, forget it.  Make more techno, Dan, please.  [h1]Conclusion[/h1]  Don't buy this game. There are dozens if not hundreds of incremental/clicker/progressing games on Steam for free. Try some of those.

In electromagnetism, a dielectric (or dielectric material or dielectric medium) is an electrical insulator that can be polarised by an applied electric field. When a dielectric material is placed in an electric field, electric charges do not flow through the material as they do in an electrical conductor, because they have no loosely bound, or free, electrons that may drift through the material, but instead they shift, only slightly, from their average equilibrium positions, causing dielectric polarisation. Because of dielectric polarisation, positive charges are displaced in the direction of the field and negative charges shift in the direction opposite to the field (for example, if the field is moving parallel to the positive x axis, the negative charges will shift in the negative x direction). This creates an internal electric field that reduces the overall field within the dielectric itself. If a dielectric is composed of weakly bonded molecules, those molecules not only become polarised, but also reorient so that their symmetry axes align to the field.

Sometimes, things are better left unchanged in the past. This is the moral of Stephen King's 11.22.63, and it's the lesson taught to unfortunate souls ponying up $5 for a desperate shot of cookie nostalgia. I feel as if we've wrenched open a time capsule buried during the Chernobyl cleanup process. This forefather of the clicker genre should have been left in peace, visible only as a website that doesn't work after the death of Macromedia Flash. There isn't anything fun about this game anymore and it even requires a smattering of non-Steam-Compatible mods to make any progress. There are dozens, even hundreds, of idle/clicker games out there with incredible depth and variety and they all owe a massive debt to Cookie Clicker. Unfortunately, it appears that CC has chosen this moment to collect $4.99 at a time. As someone with 10k hours in NGU IDLE, let me assure you this is a hard pass.

In general you can have a decent time in this game but over all i am not really sure wether i'd recommend it or not. Seeing that the reviews are overwhelmingly positive already i thought i'd not recommend it and list my problems with the game, since i don't think that rating is deserved.  1. The game is too active There is no offline progression at first and even after maxing it later you still get far more by leaving the game running. I really dislike when developers do this since it really encourages you to let the game run over night. That being said, the main reason this game is too active are the golden cookies. Those are periodically appearing icons that, once clicked, give you bonuses. This would be fine, and many games do this too, but the boni you get are so increadibly strong that not staying vigilant and clicking the golden cookies nets you so much fewer income that it becomes no contest. Later on you get the possibility to have more of an idle playstyle but nothing will come close to layering the golden cookie bonuses on top of each other.  2. The game is short Very, very short. I played the game way back when for a bit, never got to actually ascend. When it released on steam i thought to give it a shot again, so my experience was close to that of a new player. There is one prestige mechanic and nothing after that. Prestigeing for the first time with 450 prestige currency took 2 days for me and another 3 days later i am at 150 million prestige currency (playing actively). So after not even 5 days i have seen most of the prestige tree, so the only thing that's left is getting the rest of the tree for some more % bonuses and getting the rest of the achievements (some of which take a very long time). If you can stick with the game until you reach either of these you can spent a while in it (according to the internet) but the only thing you`ll get are some minor bonuses to a system you already know. There is no new prestige tier, you will have maxed out all the available buildings and the general system of how you get income will no longer change.  3. The minigames And the associated sugar lumps. Essentially you wait 24 hours to unlock one of 4 "minigames" and after that you will get 1% income bonus to one of the buildings. Considering this with the pervious point made, this system rather seems like a sinical joke than an actual system. And the minigames you unlock are... well. I`d say there only is one, the others are stale by doing the same thing every time, sometimes even without an interval just once per ascension. Essentially if you consider being able to click a button once in a while for more income a minigame, then these are for you.  Now as mentioned i focused heavily on the negative parts of the game and only mentioned things i found negative. There is more to it than this, just that these things outweigh the good for me. But in the end i can only repeat myself: you can have a decent time in this game and many people seem to agree. So if you wanna give it a shot, i won`t judge you.

I hate being the discordant voice but somebody has to.  What is the point of "idle games"? Time gated progression that keeps on going even when offline. I know this game is old but what's the point of an idle game if i have to grind the life out of it before i can go offline without completely stopping my progression?   Even if you used an autoclicker you'd still need a couple of dozens of hours of it doing work as you buy buildings to reach to a point where you can buy the upgrades that give you atleast 8 hours of optimal offline progression and, if you do that, you've pretty much wasted your first ascension because other than the prestige production bonus you'd be left without many other upgrades so you'd be starting from "scratch" depending on how deep you went into the rabbit hole in your first ascension leaving the pc on at all times.  The game is fun and has a lot of stuff to sink your time on later on, but unless you are ready to leave the pc on at all times, want to use an autoclicker (which kind of ruins the game) or have tons of free time....i can't see it working.  Right now i turned it off. 20 hours of playtime, 3 of them with an autoclicker mod just for science. I'm still a long way of making it viable to just turning it off as right now my progression is completely halted. It's kind of annoying since the sole purpose of this game is to make a number grow bigger but the game will have you kidnapped into it until it's big enough the first times.  Clicker heroes is almost as old as this....and leaving all of CH faults aside.... atleast that game got this thing right

Very selfish game with no respect for the players' time. Cookie Clicker wants you to constantly pay attention to it despite it being an incremental game, a genre of game that you're not supposed to give constant attention to. Here's a list of offenses:  -[b]No offline progress.[/b] Offline progress for incremental games is pretty standard, so the fact that this game doesn't have it is insane. There's an upgrade you can get later on where you unlock offline progress, but it's so miniscule it might as well not even exist (5% production for the first hour, then 0.5% from then on). I wouldn't have an issue with this if the absence of this feature was compensated for in other areas. Spoiler warning: it doesn't.  -[b]Requires constant attention.[/b] Progressing at any decent rate requires you to pay attention to the game at nearly all times, since the only form of automation is how many cookies per second you make. This is understandable at the beginning of the game since you get buildings and upgrades pretty quickly, and random golden cookie spawns and seasonal objects can be clicked on to give you even more cookies. Unfortunately, time between buildings and upgrades eventually becomes so long that you depend on golden cookie spawns since building production amounts are several magnitudes lower than what they cost. I have other games and priorities that vye for my attention, so this is just not fun to deal with.  -[b]Can't run in background without performance hit.[/b] This point is an extension of the previous one, but I felt it was appropriate to separate it. It's pretty common to run incremental games in the background while you do other things and occasionally check back. Again, Cookie Clicker is a selfish game, even on the lowest settings. Doing anything with Cookie Clicker running in the background will cause a noticeable performance hit, be it an FPS hit in your game or a chugging internet browser. And no, it's not my computer. I have an i7-7700 CPU and 16 GB of RAM.  -[b]Progression keeps slowing down.[/b] The gap between building costs and cookie production keeps increasing, the amount of cookies you need to produce to receive heavenly chips (needed to put points into the ascension tree, which the costs of everything at the very start are very high btw) increases exponentially, and golden cookie spawns help less and less, even after I installed a mod that clicks the cookies for me as soon as they spawn. You do get sugar lumps that let you upgrade buildings and unlock minigames, but the minigames are either small buffs or require even more attention to the game. I'm not going to leave my computer running for days just so I can get the next heavenly chip that requires me to make 2.000e15 cookies when I'm only producing 4.143e8 cookies per second.  Cookie Clicker at first glance appears to be a solid incremental game, especially with the ascension skill tree, but the above issues leaves a sour taste in my mouth with how little the game respects my time. I don't think I'll bother, I have more important things to attend to.

Assuming you know what Cookie Clicker is, I cannot recommend this version of the game for one reason, that being the game takes an immense amount of time for anything to occur. Playing the game is a chore, especially early on, and honestly I'm not sure if you are intended to play through it all or just keep it open in the background. There are upgrades allowing you to generate cookies while offline, but they come later in the game and are honestly insulting as they give but a fraction of your total cookie production. I just can't comprehend what the average player is meant to do here. Other idle games have no problem calculating offline progress. I want to give the game a positive review for its other elements that I think are enjoyable but the fact that I have to keep the game on overnight to make any sort of decent progress is a big turn-off for me.

Day 1, She yelled at me for the first time in three years, we've never had a fight like this before and we have been married for almost six years. It scared me, honestly, but the game isn't doing me any harm, I don't understand why she wants me to turn it off. I don't even have it up, it just stays minimized, I don't get her problem.  Day 10,  She is threatening to take the kids if I don't stop playing this game, I don't get it, but I told her today that I got rid of it on my Steam account, she seems to be fine and today we finally held each other in the sweet embrace of love for the first time since I started playing. Little does she know, I just hid it on my task bar...  Day 38, She caught me. Omg, she broke my keyboard (luckily I had another in the closet) and screamed at me from playing it again. She didn't even let me say anything, she just started packing her things and grabbed Mike and Laura's hands *(my two children) and got in the car and left for her Mom's house. I just sat there and cried on the couch as the beautiful clicking sounds of that cookie with C418's music played softly in the background.  Day 40, Her Mom called me and asked what happened, to which I tried to explain, but Katie *(my wife of six years now) hung up the phone before yelling "GET OFF OF THAT STUPID F****** GAME OR I'M SENDING THE PAPERS". I just stood there and began to cry as the music kept going in the background.  Day 69, I signed the divorce papers today. I don't know why, but suddenly I'm finding cookies in my shelves. I don't even know why they are there, I haven't bought cookies, have I? My boss caught me playing it at work, but he tapped me on the shoulder and winked saying "Don't worry, I play it too". He is such a good guy, gave me a raise when he heard about what happened.   Day 72,  Mike and Laura called me today, it was the first time I've heard their voice since Katie left. A bit sad, but they refuse to call me Dad anymore, Katie said I don't have to pay child support and she doesn't want to court saying "You wouldn't even come, you just stay on that f***ing idle game all day."  Day 200,  It's been over a year now. Cookie Clicker is all I have now in terms of family and love. I am working as the Executive Assistant to my Boss who is now the CEO of the company. I no longer remember my old families faces. All I know is Cookie Clicker. Do not send help . Cookie Clicker as a social commentary  This is not just a game about cookies but a commentary on Capitalism. throughout the game you employ the services of grandmas to bake cookies for you but still requires user input to gain cookies , the further you progress the grandmas become sick of continued abuse from the cookie monopoly you have created, User input becomes futile but rather the user sits back and watches the grandmas slave away for you. The game teaches the user that exploitation of the working class leads to vast wealth , wealth that you cannot spend but rather hoard.

i swear to the Grandmatriarchs, this game is a black hole and i can't stop playing it i leave it open for long stretches of time and interact with the game in the background as i do the things i normally do sometimes the playtime doesn't even track for days, BUT I DON'T CARE  this game is unironically addicting... i can't stop... it's consumed my life... as of typing this i have 363 out of 532 achievements (68.23%), and i still feel like i have to keep going  it started out so simple. you buy a cursor. you buy a grandma. now i'm steadily upgrading my fractal engines and idleverses, waiting until the next milk flavor unlocks (who knew there were so many???) all the while my CpS (cookies per second) is being boosted by my eldritch cosmic horror Santa Claus and my sweet cookie dragon named Krumblor who smells of milk and has a big appetite.  you can literally give your cookies to Satan, Asmodeus, Beelzebub, and Lucifer to be allowed to retain cookie production while your game is closed (even though i never close it). your grandmas create a terrifying grandma hivemind, continuing to produce cookies even as their physical body wastes away.  TL;DR - this game can be very time consuming (started two months ago and still playing), it's an AMAZING game to occupy yourself with (especially for someone with ADHD), and the sense of progression may be slow at first but it feels awesome! it's only 4.99, support Orteil and try out this fantastic game!

Why do I do this to myself? Why do I install idle games thinking that this time will be different? I've already played dozens and I know what to expect. No interesting decisions. Hardly any participatory gameplay. Just a genre that's defined by marking your progress in the game with the actual progress of time. Games you play by not playing them, checking in periodically to buy some upgrades so that you will progress faster while you don't play them. Marking out seconds, minutes, hours of your time by making numbers go up in a game that doesn't need your intervention or attention. You could cease to exist, and Cookie Clicker would still keep progressing. Is that why we play them? Are idle games a chance at immortality? Even after we die, after we turn to dust, after nobody speaks our names, we will still be accumulating cookies even as the stars wink out and reality ends and transforms into something new, something different. Will we reemerge, shedding our physical forms to become light, to become electricity, free of the physical shackles which once ensnared us, and in our new way of being all we will carry with us are the electronic cookies that we made?

Classic and one of the first idler incremental games. Really should cost $4.99 + the cost of a new mouse.  Anyway, while the game is fine and overall fun, there are a few big issues that keep me from giving it a thumbs up at this time.  First, there are some bugs with the port. Sometimes the game doesn't save properly and/or sync with the cloud saving. Minor issues where you can just copy your save code and import it and such.  But the bigger issue is that there's no way to play other games on Steam while it is running. Normally, when it runs in a browser, it is in the background and isn't a big deal. But the way Steam works means you can't have 2 games playing at the same time with them both being online at the same time. I could go "offline" on one computer running it but then I might as well just use the browser, plus that requires 2 computers.  I wish they would enable a way for the game to be closed and still function at 100% ... they would need to rework how the "idle while game is closed" bonuses for other things work, but it would free up the ability to play other Steam games while also "playing" Cookie Clicker.  If they can fix these two issues the game would definitely be a thumbs up for the nostalgia, history, and overall decent idle gameplay.  P.S. I hope some other idlers/incrementals come to Steam... maybe in some group bundle including: Candy Box 1/2, A Dark Room, Crank, Universal Paperclips, The Prestige Tree, Antimatter Dimensions, and others.  EDIT: The main issue I was having was due to cloud saving sync issues with Steam. The issue still remains if you have Cookie Clicker running on one computer and want to play a game on the other. No easy way to solve this since it is on Steam's hands, but it would be nice if Cookie Clicker had an "offline idle" with 100% values instead of requiring upgrades. Steam is a different platform than browsers and as such should be designed slightly differently.

If you like idle games, skip this game, NGU Idle or Clicker Heroes are way better than anything this could ever be. I have no idea why people are reviewing this so highly or why it's so raved about. No offline production until you're really deep into the ascension upgrade tree, people making mods so that idling is more viable. What a state of a game, honestly. Honestly, 100+ hours in and it's still one of the least engaging idle/clicker games I've encountered. The presentation is well done, but the mechanics are extremely dull and any real choice is limited. I hear cheating is common practice and even sanctioned by the dev in some cases, and I can see why, as without it, it's so linear that I might as well 'play' a screensaver. Compared to Adventure Capitalist this game is shorter and more dependent on both luck and active-play.  + No micro-transactions + Decent progression through achievements and restarts + Numbers go up + Enjoyed running through the main game, maxing building and heavenly upgrades  - Luck plays a significant factor  - Confusing. To really progress through the main game requires a decent amount of active play trying to get golden cookie combos, but once you've unlocked all of that you're suddenly gated by weeks to months of waiting for "sugar lumps" to grow. - Personally I did not enjoy the "minigames" like garden or stock exchange. They're a frustrating combination of relying on luck whilst being forced to wait yet forced to pay attention.  TLDR: The main game is reasonable fun for a few £. Uninstall after getting all the building unlocks. Don't bother with "sugar lumps" or minigames.  Ideally I'd give this a neutral rating, but that's not an option.

Cookie Clicker is damaging to yourself and those around you.  Cookie Clicker is an addiction. Based on my extensive naturalistic observation, I have seen how far a person can and will go in order to keep clicking cookies. This behavior is very closely related to the behavior of addicts, supporting my statement about Cookie Clicker being an addiction.  Cookie Clicker is the only thing on the effected person's mind. Even during the short periods where Cookie Clicker is not being played, the addicted individual will talk about Cookie Clicker any chance they get. Unfortunately, many people I know have faced this horrible addiction and I have seen how it takes over their minds. One time, while I was helping an addicted child overcome his problem, another addicted man came and stole the conversation from me turning it into a twisted talk of obsession. There was another time that really stood out in my mind about how Cookie Clicker is always on the effected individual's mind. I was in the car with two addicted individuals and was trying to have a normal, healthy, conversation with one. Sadly, the other person interrupted the conversation to talk about his cookies, and in doing so, he ruined a game that me and the other addicted person have been playing for years. That was truly a soul crushing moment for me.  As the addiction gets worse, the effected person will forgo any form of healthy social interaction to feed his addiction. There have been many times where I would try to enjoy some social time with a person who is addicted to Cookie Clicker, but they will always choose the game over real people. Sometimes, although it is rare, they will participate in social activity, but their thoughts are quickly consumed by cookies and it shows in their choice of conversation.  Like any addiction, the Cookie Clicker addiction is damaging to those who care for the addicted individual. The addiction will cause those who care for the effected person to feel guilty. The addicted person's family may feel responsible for that person's addiction. They will question how they have allowed them to develop an addiction, or perhaps they fought hard to help the addicted individual but were not able to help. Regardless of the circumstances, those who are close to the addicted individual will carry guilt and blame themselves to a certain extent.  As I mentioned earlier, I know people that are effected by this horrid game. I have seen others try to explain to them how damaging a simple game could be but they refuse to listen, and to some extent, those people blame themselves for not trying hard enough and letting them get sucked into this dark place. Another way it could affect those around the effected person is by them downplaying the problem. Like any addiction, people close to the person could just live in denial about the effected person's problem. They might make excuses for the person's behavior or downplay the problem. They could also be scared about addressing the issue, worried about the possible future for the person, so they choose to ignore it instead of dealing with it.  At first I thought that this Cookie Clicker was a simple, although completely boring, game. Oh how wrong I was. The game slowly consumes the players, like a child eating cookies. I thought it was just going to be another game that people would quickly get bored of or forget about a few days later, and because of these thoughts, the Cookie Clicker addiction had time to fully manifest itself in their minds, since no one was trying to stop them. Another way it damages those around the addicted person, is that the addiction controls their mind. When people are addicted to something their whole life revolves around the addiction. It consumes their mind turning them into a different person, which is scary to those around them. Instead of the person seeing you as someone who cares for them, they will only see you as someone who is getting in the way of the only thing they care about, Cookie Clicker. You can try all you want to help the person get over this Cookie Clicker, but they won't see it that way. You could turn the computer off, but instead of the nice person you knew and cared for they will turn into some monster, screaming at you for making them lose their precious cookies. They are no longer the person you cared for.  Playing Cookie Clicker even just once is dangerous. Like any addictive thing, it may take only one time to become addicted. Cookie Clicker has just enough stuff for someone to keep on "playing" right from the beginning. At first you start with nothing, but as you continue clicking you gather enough cookies for upgrades, which make it so you can get more cookies faster, making you repeat an endless cycle of pain.  Cookie Clicker also has achievements for you to get, which keeps you hooked on the game. Not only does it have the upgrades that were mentioned earlier, but it also has achievements. Some of these achievement titles prove that the creators of the game are well aware that it's an addiction by having the achievement titles relate to drug use. One achievement is "So baked right now", another is "Overdose", and these sayings clearly show the relations to drug use.  Even if you manage to beat this addiction there is always the possibility of having a relapse. Unfortunately, no one I know has overcome this problem, but based on my knowledge of addictions, it's a very real possibility that they could suffer from a relapse. Relapses are a miserable part of addiction, even after you overcome the problem there is still a chance it could come back at any time. Possibly because of stress, negative emotions, really strong cravings, or being around things that remind you of Cookie Clicker. It is very damaging to your life and you might have to avoid cookies for the rest of your life unless you want to relapse. So you shouldn't play the game, even just once.  By now you should realize how dangerous this so called "game" is and the harmful effects it has on not only the player, but also those who care for the player. I truly hope that this paper will open people's eyes about this so called game, and that anyone who reads this won't let anyone they care for get sucked into this Cookie Clicker.

It's cookie clicker. It pioneered the clicker genre, almost single-handedly. It's what it says on the tin. It is an excellent clicker game, and you would be insane not to buy it if you enjoy those kinds of games.  Only qualm I have with it right now - It's quite badly optimised on steam and runs quite badly on my fairly decent pc (specs on my profile if you're curious). Which is surprising because I've played it before for days on a terrible, old laptop that struggled to play the Sims 2. So for now, until a hot-patch comes out that fixes this optimisation issue, I'm not recommending it and I'd suggest you go on the free web-page version of the game if your PC isn't the greatest - and then import your web browser save over to the steam version when it's fixed.   But this is definitely a limitation of the steam reviews, because I absolutely recommend this game - just maybe not QUITE in it's current state.  Edit for the game award badge.

Before you flame this review to note that "Clicker" is literally right there in the name and I should have known better:  1) the game tags list "Clicker" and "Idler" as the top two tags 2) This genre as a whole tends to wrestle with how to appeal to both camps, often being better at one than the other.    As such, this is really a neutral review.  In short, Cookie Clicker is a good active clicker game, but not much of an idler.   Until your first ascension you won't gain any progress off-line, and even leaving the game running in the background, your progress will be significantly hampered both because of the need to buy upgrades and grandmas steadliy, but moreso because clicking Golden Cookies and later also wrinklers are a huge percentage of your revenue, and farms and towers will also require some regular attention. As a result it feels to me like the game doesn't really value strategy either, it really just values in-game time and clicking.  I'd say if you want a very active clicker game that you can dedicate a lot of time to paying attention to, Cookie Clicker does have a lot of charm (albeit the text flashes at the top get old very quickly) and a lot of bells and whistles to keep you clicking.  If you're wanting something you can really walk away from, and still feel like you're progressing, Cookie Clicker really isn't that game.
