Cookie Clicker is an incremental game created by French programmer Julien "Orteil" Thiennot in 2013. The user initially clicks on a big cookie on the screen, earning a single cookie per click. They can then spend their earned cookies upon purchasing assets such as "cursors" and other "buildings" that automatically produce cookies. Upgrades are also available and can improve the efficiency of clicks and buildings, among many other mechanics that allow the user to earn cookies in different ways. Though the game has no ending, it has hundreds of achievements, and users may aim to reach milestone numbers of cookies.  The game is one of the first and most important in the genre of incremental games and has a dedicated fanbase. Though the first version was coded in one night, Cookie Clicker is regularly updated. It has been widely described as addictive, and it has been noted that the game almost does not require a human to play it.  At first, the player clicks on the large cookie on the far left side of the screen, earning one cookie per click. With these cookies, the player can buy new assets such as cursors, grandmas, farms, mines, factories and banks that automatically make cookies. Prices increase exponentially, each asset costing 15% more than the last-purchased asset of the same type. Golden cookies, small cookies that appear in random locations and fade away after several seconds, appear periodically and grant effects, such as bonus cookies, or a temporary increase in the rate of production if clicked before they disappear.  After earning a certain number of cookies, the player can 'ascend', losing their progress but earning heavenly chips and prestige levels. Prestige levels add a permanent boost (+1% per level) to the rate of cookie production in future play-throughs, while heavenly chips can be spent on a wide variety of prestige upgrades. Note, however, that the cookies needed to unlock the next prestige level goes up exponentially with the cube of the level, becoming harder to attain as you get more of them. Other game mechanics include "wrinklers" (eldritch beasts which reduce cookie production, but can be popped by clicking on them, returning all the cookies it digested with interest), the Cookie Dragon, mini games, and sugar lumps (which take 24 hours to coalesce and are used to level up buildings and boost their production rate). Achievements can be earned by completing various tasks or goals, such as reaching a certain number of total cookies produced, owning a particular number of buildings of a certain type or clicking a certain number of golden cookies. Additionally, seasonal events occur during their respective holidays which come with more upgrades and cookies to unlock.  The game features geometric growth: the player begins baking handfuls of cookies, but can quickly reach billions of cookies, and eventually attain duodecillions of cookies or beyond. The game has no clear ending.  Because of the game's relatively simple code, cheats and add-ons are widely available and simply implemented by using browser consoles and bookmarklets.  Julien "Orteil" Thiennot created Cookie Clicker in August 2013. Written in a single evening, the game was posted in a link on 4chan, and garnered 50,000 players within hours. A month after the game's initial release, it had over 200,000 players per day. Orteil later wrote that traffic had peaked at 1.5 million hits in one day during August 2013, and as of January 2014 Cookie Clicker was still getting a steady 225,000 hits per day. The game has had continual updates since its release, notably the "legacy" update in February 2016 and the "spiritual" update in July 2017. On October 25, 2018, Orteil launched the game's Patreon page, with the intent to develop Cookie Clicker and other Dashnet games becoming a full-time job. On August 8, 2019, the mobile beta for Cookie Clicker was released for Android devices after a long delay.  Cookie Clicker is similar to Cow Clicker, a previously existing idle game created by Ian Bogost. Bogost has called Cookie Clicker "the logical conclusion of Cow Clicker". Orteil later released other idle games such as: Idle Game Maker, a tool allowing customized idle games to be made without coding knowledge; AdventureQuest Dragons, a mobile game created with Artix Entertainment; and Neverending Legacy.  Steam release On August 8, 2021, Orteil announced on Twitter a Steam release of Cookie Clicker, with the planned release date of September 1, 2021. The game was released on Steam on its originally announced release date. The release also consisted of a soundtrack composed by C418.
Waste of time.

Only 5$. Pretty straight forward. I never heard of the web browser version but many people talk about it. So it's actually a ported version of the web browser one with tons of achievements.   I was going to complain about the fact that there is no offline progression (when the game is closed) but doing some quick research, it's in fact something you have to unlock after you prestige. So it can be annoying at first when you don't have it because you literally can't progress if the game is not running. But I guess after that it's much easier. It's very interesting design. I like it!  Overall for the price, can only recommend it. I even bought it as a gift for my friend who is enjoying clicker and is an achievements hunter :P
OG Clicker Game /10

I was really looking forward to this game and was greatly disappointed. To say the game is confusing to play would be an understatement. Yes, games are all about discovery and trying things out and yada yada yada but this game just hides the main, core, game play mechanics behind vague descriptions in the hope that you will accidentally make the wrong choice and prolong the game play out another week in order to recover from your ill informed decision. If you play it, you will probably spend more time in the first 10 hours reading online guides that explain what to do than actually playing the game, and if you're reading a guide in the first 10 hours of the game rather than enjoying it is a major red flag (and those that say they didn't read a guide, well, you were lucky and made the right choices) .... this game might as well say 'hit this button, I'm not going to tell you what it does, but I have 50 other buttons that I'm not going to tell you what they do either so get used to it, oh, and here is like 12 choices, pick 3, but it's going to be impossible to work out if the 3 you choose are beneficial to you .. .have you tried reading a guide on the optimal choices". This type of game play is incredibly frustrating. It shouldn't be like this for a game that you are just starting out playing. The game should be a lot more intuitive to the player experience. If you're literally going to invest hundreds of hours (like you need to in this game) it shouldn't be this hard. You shouldn't have a vague description over a selection that once you choose you have no idea what has happened....... so do you prestige at 1 heavenly chip after the first couple of hours of play, or 835 heavenly chips after leaving the game running for a week? Several online guides give different advice. the game though .. tells you nothing (oh sorry , it does,  it tells you you can do it at 1 .. but quick tip, don't do it after 1)

This game saved my life.  I am 38.  My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.  When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.  After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.  Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.  After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.  Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.  I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.  Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.  Thank you.

Okay, so after reading the positive reviews here I'm just wondering 'what am I missing' ?  After 70+ hours this game is  S  L  O  W. My 70+ hours have been spent using an auto-clicker, which would probably equal about 3 weeks if clicking manually, and I've prestiged once. That prestige made zero difference to the gameplay speed. I wasn't expecting to complete the game, but this is just ridiculous.  I'm a big fan of idle/clickers, so I'm not new to the genre, but if you try to play this mainly as an idler, instead of a clicker,  you will be playing this game for YEARS. Even that isn't necessarily a bad point, IF the game has things to do whilst your playing. This doesn't, it's slow AND boring. Can't recommend this game from what I've seen so far.

I would advise caution when looking at recommendations of this game, too often people are willing to give glowing reviews of a game, as if there is nothing that can be wrong with it, all for what amounts to favor with a developer and the future potential of special treatment in return, a simple concept only definable as corruption. This game could be great on here but I have to currently outright reject it for the following reasons:  1. The game just crashes only 1 minute after it loads up, the game goes white screen and i have no choice but to close it, music still playing. 2. When the game closes in this fashion, the process of said game remains, this comes off as amateurish at best. Regardless of my capabilities, it doesn't change it from being what it is. Additional Problem 3. When you fix the errors above by replacing the libGLESv2.dll with a new version you can download for free, the game will now instead just load up occasionally to a black screen. Maybe it's trying to load my gigantic save from browser versions, (since it's literally no different from it atm) but the game sorely lacks some kind of indicator of this.  I would advise that Orteil work on the above points, and I would also advise he remember to make sure his stuff works before charging money for it. I would also like to suggest that Point 2 be looked at as if it happens regardless of any game closure method, the process persisting comes off as sloppy, but that's just my opinion.  With the game in its current state I couldn't recommend this unless you literally paid me 2000 USD. If you buy this, don't be upset if it has the problems I mentioned, simply just ignore it exists and play the browser version, after all, a few aesthetic changes like music or graphics isn't going to improve a game to a degree that matters.  I may be harsh here, but the developer isn't new and I believe he can handle some harsh criticism. It feels like he isn't bringing his A-game for something he's charging money for now.

I love cookie clicker, and have for years. Orteil's visual style and sense of humor are very charming, and the game is fun enough to be played actively, while still being rewarding when left to run passively in the background. Last time I played was before the addition of the minigames and extra features that the sugar lumps can unlock, and they add a lot for people who want to dig a little deeper into the game. I've been playing it while writing an essay, and it is just enough to keep me entertained and prevent me from falling into another more distracting game. The rush of getting two golden cookie buffs to stack is unrivaled.

Cookie Clicker is the best idle game I've ever played! The game is free on a web browser so feel free to try it there if you're unsure but the steam version is a great way to support the developer. This is the perfect game to keep up in the background as you work or play other games. Although it's an idler, there's enough going on that you'll usually be doing more than just letting it run in the background. It's also nice that there's almost no need to keep it open when you're asleep or not home so you're not wasting electricity.
